<p>The <b>Indian Space Research Organisation</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a href="#cite_note-6">[a]</a></sup> (<b>ISRO</b>; <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/oʊ/: 'o' in 'code'">oʊ</span></span>/</a></span></span>) is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Government_space_agency" title="Government space agency">national space agency</a> of <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, headquartered in <a href="/wiki/Bangalore" title="Bangalore">Bangalore</a>. It operates under the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Space" title="Department of Space">Department of Space</a> (DOS) which is directly overseen by the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India" title="Prime Minister of India">Prime Minister of India</a>, while the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chairman_of_ISRO" title="Chairman of ISRO">Chairman of ISRO</a> acts as the executive of DOS as well. ISRO is India's primary agency for performing tasks related to space-based applications, <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration" title="Space exploration">space exploration</a> and the development of related technologies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-isro_aboutus_7-0"><a href="#cite_note-isro_aboutus-7">[6]</a></sup> It is one of six government space agencies in the world which possess full launch capabilities, deploy <a href="/wiki/Cryogenic_rocket_engine" title="Cryogenic rocket engine">cryogenic engines</a>, launch <a href="/wiki/List_of_Solar_System_probes" title="List of Solar System probes">extraterrestrial missions</a> and operate large fleets of artificial satellites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cryo14_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cryo14-8">[7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarveySmidPirard2011144–_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarveySmidPirard2011144–-9">[8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[b]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Committee_for_Space_Research" title="Indian National Committee for Space Research">Indian National Committee for Space Research</a> (INCOSPAR) was established by <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Atomic_Energy" title="Department of Atomic Energy">Department of Atomic Energy</a> (DAE) in 1962, on the urging of scientist <a href="/wiki/Vikram_Sarabhai" title="Vikram Sarabhai">Vikram Sarabhai</a>, recognising the need in space research. INCOSPAR grew and became ISRO in 1969, within DAE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DAE_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-DAE-11">[9]</a></sup> In 1972, the government of India set up a Space Commission and DOS, bringing ISRO under it. The establishment of ISRO thus institutionalised space research activities in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhargavaChakrabarti200339_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhargavaChakrabarti200339-12">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESadeh2013303-_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESadeh2013303--13">[11]</a></sup> It since then has been managed by DOS, which governs various other institutions in India in the domain of astronomy and space technology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DOSHQ_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-DOSHQ-14">[12]</a></sup>
</p><p>ISRO built India's first <a href="/wiki/Satellite" title="Satellite">satellite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aryabhata_(satellite)" title="Aryabhata (satellite)">Aryabhata</a>, which was <a href="/wiki/Interkosmos" title="Interkosmos">launched by the Soviet Union</a> in 1975.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Aryabhatta_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-Aryabhatta-15">[13]</a></sup> In 1980, ISRO launched satellite <a href="/wiki/Rohini_(satellite)" title="Rohini (satellite)">RS-1</a> onboard its own <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SLV-3" title="SLV-3">SLV-3</a>, making India the <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_first_orbital_launches_by_country" title="Timeline of first orbital launches by country">seventh country</a> to be capable of undertaking orbital launches. SLV-3 was followed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ASLV" title="ASLV">ASLV</a>, which was subsequently succeeded by development of many <a href="/wiki/Medium-lift_launch_vehicle" title="Medium-lift launch vehicle">medium-lift launch vehicles</a>, rocket engines, satellite systems and networks enabling the agency to launch hundreds of domestic and foreign satellites and various deep space missions for <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration" title="Space exploration">space exploration</a>.
</p><p>ISRO has the world's largest constellation of remote-sensing satellites and operates the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GAGAN" title="GAGAN">GAGAN</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NAVIC" title="NAVIC">NAVIC</a> <a href="/wiki/Satellite_navigation" title="Satellite navigation">satellite navigation</a> systems. It has sent <a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan_programme" title="Chandrayaan programme">two missions</a> to the Moon and <a href="/wiki/Mars_Orbiter_Mission" title="Mars Orbiter Mission">one to Mars</a>.
</p><p>Goals in near future include expanding satellites fleet, <a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan-3" title="Chandrayaan-3">landing a rover on Moon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indian_Human_Spaceflight_Programme" title="Indian Human Spaceflight Programme">sending humans into space</a>, <a href="/wiki/SCE-200" title="SCE-200">development of a semi-cryogenic engine</a>, sending more unmanned missions to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Exploration_of_Moon" title="Exploration of Moon">Moon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Exploration_of_Mars" title="Exploration of Mars">Mars</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Exploration_of_Venus" title="Exploration of Venus">Venus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sun" title="Sun">Sun</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_space_telescopes" title="List of space telescopes">deployment of more space telescopes</a> in orbit to observe cosmic phenomena and outerspace beyond the <a href="/wiki/Solar_System" title="Solar System">Solar System</a>. Long-term plans include development of <a href="/wiki/Reusable_launch_vehicle" title="Reusable launch vehicle">reusable launchers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Heavy-lift_launch_vehicle" title="Heavy-lift launch vehicle">heavy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Super_heavy-lift_launch_vehicle" title="Super heavy-lift launch vehicle">super heavy launch vehicles</a>, deploying a <a href="/wiki/Space_station" title="Space station">space station</a>, sending exploration missions to external planets like <a href="/wiki/Exploration_of_Jupiter" title="Exploration of Jupiter">Jupiter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Exploration_of_Uranus" title="Exploration of Uranus">Uranus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Exploration_of_Neptune" title="Exploration of Neptune">Neptune</a> and asteroids and manned missions to moons and planets.
</p><p>ISRO's programs have played a significant role in the socio-economic development of India and have supported both civilian and military domains in various aspects including disaster management, telemedicine and navigation and reconnaissance missions. <a href="/wiki/ISRO_spinoff_technologies" title="ISRO spinoff technologies">ISRO's spin off technologies</a> also have founded many crucial innovations for India's engineering and medical industries.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Formative_years">Formative years</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=2" title="Edit section: Formative years">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TERLS-03.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="233" data-file-width="353" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/TERLS-03.jpg/220px-TERLS-03.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/TERLS-03.jpg/330px-TERLS-03.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c2/TERLS-03.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TERLS-03.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An <a href="/wiki/Arcas_(rocket)" title="Arcas (rocket)">Arcas rocket</a> being loaded into launch tube at <a href="/wiki/Thumba_Equatorial_Rocket_Launching_Station" title="Thumba Equatorial Rocket Launching Station">Thumba Launching Station</a>. In the early days of ISRO, rocket parts were often transported on bicycles and bullock carts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[14]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Modern space research in India can be traced to the 1920s, when scientist <a href="/wiki/Sisir_Kumar_Mitra" title="Sisir Kumar Mitra">S. K. Mitra</a> conducted a series of experiments sounding of the <a href="/wiki/Ionosphere" title="Ionosphere">ionosphere</a> through ground-based radio in <a href="/wiki/Kolkata" title="Kolkata">Kolkata</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992486_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992486-17">[15]</a></sup> Later, Indian scientists like <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/C.V._Raman" title="C.V. Raman">C.V. Raman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Meghnad_Saha" title="Meghnad Saha">Meghnad Saha</a> contributed to scientific principles applicable in space sciences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992486_17-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992486-17">[15]</a></sup> After 1945, important developments were made in coordinated space research in India<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992486_17-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992486-17">[15]</a></sup> by two scientists: <a href="/wiki/Vikram_Sarabhai" title="Vikram Sarabhai">Vikram Sarabhai</a>—founder of the <a href="/wiki/Physical_Research_Laboratory" title="Physical Research Laboratory">Physical Research Laboratory</a> at <a href="/wiki/Ahmedabad" title="Ahmedabad">Ahmedabad</a>—and <a href="/wiki/Homi_J._Bhabha" title="Homi J. Bhabha">Homi Bhabha</a>, who established the <a href="/wiki/Tata_Institute_of_Fundamental_Research" title="Tata Institute of Fundamental Research">Tata Institute of Fundamental Research</a> in 1945.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992486_17-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992486-17">[15]</a></sup> Initial experiments in space sciences included the study of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cosmic_rays" title="Cosmic rays">cosmic radiation</a>, high altitude and airborne testing, deep underground experimentation at the <a href="/wiki/Particle_experiments_at_Kolar_Gold_Fields" title="Particle experiments at Kolar Gold Fields">Kolar mines</a>—one of the deepest mining sites in the world—and studies of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Earth%27s_atmosphere" title="Earth's atmosphere">upper atmosphere</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992487_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992487-18">[16]</a></sup> These studies were done at research laboratories, universities, and independent locations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992487_18-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992487-18">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992488_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992488-19">[17]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1950, the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Atomic_Energy" title="Department of Atomic Energy">Department of Atomic Energy</a> (DAE) was founded with Bhabha as its <a href="/wiki/Secretary_to_the_Government_of_India" title="Secretary to the Government of India">secretary</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992488_19-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992488-19">[17]</a></sup> It provided funding for space research throughout India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992489_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992489-20">[18]</a></sup> During this time, tests continued on aspects of <a href="/wiki/Meteorology" title="Meteorology">meteorology</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Earth%27s_magnetic_field" title="Earth's magnetic field">Earth's magnetic field</a>, a topic that had been studied in India since the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Colaba_Observatory" title="Colaba Observatory">Colaba Observatory</a> in 1823. In 1954, the <a href="/wiki/Aryabhatta_Research_Institute_of_Observational_Sciences" title="Aryabhatta Research Institute of Observational Sciences">Aryabhatta Research Institute of Observational Sciences</a> (ARIES) was established in the foothills of the Himalayas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992488_19-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992488-19">[17]</a></sup> The Rangpur Observatory was set up in 1957 at <a href="/wiki/Osmania_University" title="Osmania University">Osmania University</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hyderabad,_Andhra_Pradesh" title="Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh">Hyderabad</a>. Space research was further encouraged by the government of India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992489_20-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992489-20">[18]</a></sup> In 1957, the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> launched <a href="/wiki/Sputnik_1" title="Sputnik 1">Sputnik 1</a> and opened up possibilities for the rest of the world to conduct a space launch.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992489_20-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaniel1992489-20">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Committee_for_Space_Research" title="Indian National Committee for Space Research">Indian National Committee for Space Research</a> (INCOSPAR) was set up in 1962 by Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a> on the urging of <a href="/wiki/Vikram_Sarabhai" title="Vikram Sarabhai">Vikram Sarabhai</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESadeh2013303-_13-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESadeh2013303--13">[11]</a></sup> There was no dedicated ministry for the space program initially and all activities of INCOSPAR relating to space technology continued to function within DAE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DAE_11-1"><a href="#cite_note-DAE-11">[9]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhargavaChakrabarti200339_12-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhargavaChakrabarti200339-12">[10]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H.G.S._Murthy" title="H.G.S. Murthy">H.G.S. Murthy</a> was appointed the first director of the <a href="/wiki/Thumba_Equatorial_Rocket_Launching_Station" title="Thumba Equatorial Rocket Launching Station">Thumba Equatorial Rocket Launching Station</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[19]</a></sup> where <a href="/wiki/Sounding_rocket" title="Sounding rocket">sounding rockets</a> were fired, marking the start of upper atmospheric research in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[20]</a></sup> An indigenous series of sounding rockets named <a href="/wiki/Rohini_(rocket_family)" title="Rohini (rocket family)">Rohini</a> was subsequently developed and started undergoing launches from 1967 onwards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[21]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1970s_and_1980s">1970s and 1980s</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=3" title="Edit section: 1970s and 1980s">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Under the government of <a href="/wiki/Indira_Gandhi" title="Indira Gandhi">Indira Gandhi</a>, INCOSPAR was superseded by ISRO. Later in 1972, a space commission and <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Space" title="Department of Space">Department of Space</a> (DOS) were set up to oversee space technology development in India specifically and ISRO was brought under DOS, institutionalising space research in India and forging the Indian space program into its existing form.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhargavaChakrabarti200339_12-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhargavaChakrabarti200339-12">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DOSHQ_14-1"><a href="#cite_note-DOSHQ-14">[12]</a></sup> India joined the Soviet <a href="/wiki/Interkosmos" title="Interkosmos">Interkosmos</a> program for space cooperation<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sheehan_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sheehan-24">[22]</a></sup> and got its first satellite <a href="/wiki/Aryabhata_(satellite)" title="Aryabhata (satellite)">Aryabhatta</a> in orbit through a Soviet rocket.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Aryabhatta_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-Aryabhatta-15">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>Efforts to develop an orbital launch vehicle began after mastering sounding rocket technology. The concept was to develop a launcher capable of providing sufficient velocity for a mass of 35 kg (77 lb) to enter <a href="/wiki/Low_Earth_orbit" title="Low Earth orbit">low Earth orbit</a>. It took 7 years for ISRO to develop <a href="/wiki/Satellite_Launch_Vehicle" title="Satellite Launch Vehicle">Satellite Launch Vehicle</a> capable of putting 40 kg (88 lb) into a 400-kilometre (250 mi) orbit. An <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SLV_Launch_Pad" title="SLV Launch Pad">SLV Launch Pad</a>, ground stations, tracking networks, radars and other communications were set up for a launch campaign. The SLV's first launch in 1979 carried a <a href="/wiki/Rohini_(satellite)" title="Rohini (satellite)">Rohini technology payload</a> but could not inject the satellite into its desired orbit. It was followed by a successful launch in 1980 carrying a <a href="/wiki/Rohini_(satellite)" title="Rohini (satellite)">Rohini Series-I</a> satellite, making India the seventh country to reach Earth's orbit after the USSR, the US, France, the <a href="/wiki/Prospero_(spacecraft)" title="Prospero (spacecraft)">UK</a>, China and Japan. RS-1 was the third Indian satellite to reach orbit as <a href="/wiki/Bhaskara_(satellite)" title="Bhaskara (satellite)">Bhaskara</a> had been launched from the USSR in 1979. Efforts to develop a <a href="/wiki/Medium-lift_launch_vehicle" title="Medium-lift launch vehicle">medium-lift launch vehicle</a> capable of putting 600-kilogram (1,300 lb) class spacecrafts into 1,000-kilometre (620 mi) <a href="/wiki/Sun-synchronous_orbit" title="Sun-synchronous orbit">Sun-synchronous orbit</a> had already begun in 1978.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[23]</a></sup> They would later lead to the development of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PSLV" title="PSLV">PSLV</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SLVFlipbook_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-SLVFlipbook-26">[24]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SLV-3" title="SLV-3">SLV-3</a> later had two more launches before discontinuation in 1983.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-slv_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-slv-27">[25]</a></sup> ISRO's <a href="/wiki/Liquid_Propulsion_Systems_Centre" title="Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre">Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre</a> (LPSC) was set up in 1985 and started working on a more powerful engine, <a href="/wiki/Vikas_(rocket_engine)" title="Vikas (rocket engine)">Vikas</a>, based upon the French <a href="/wiki/Viking_(rocket_engine)" title="Viking (rocket engine)">Viking</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[26]</a></sup> Two years later, facilities to test liquid fueled rocket engines were established and development and testing of various rocket engines <a href="/wiki/Thrusters_(spacecraft)" title="Thrusters (spacecraft)">thrusters</a> began.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lpsctimeline_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-lpsctimeline-29">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the same time, another solid fueled rocket <a href="/wiki/Augmented_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle" title="Augmented Satellite Launch Vehicle">Augmented Satellite Launch Vehicle</a> based upon SLV-3 was being developed, and technologies to launch satellites into <a href="/wiki/Geostationary_orbit" title="Geostationary orbit">geostationary orbit</a> (GTO). ASLV had limited success and multiple launch failures; it was soon discontinued.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ITASLV_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-ITASLV-30">[28]</a></sup> Alongside, technologies for the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Satellite_System" title="Indian National Satellite System">Indian National Satellite System</a> of communication satellites<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[29]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Remote_Sensing_Programme" title="Indian Remote Sensing Programme">Indian Remote Sensing Programme</a> for earth observation satellites<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[30]</a></sup> were developed and launches from overseas initiated. The number of satellites eventually grew and the systems were established as among the largest satellite constellations in the world, with multi-band communication, radar imaging, optical imaging and meteorological satellites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IRSSaga_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-IRSSaga-33">[31]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1990s_and_early_21st_century">1990s and early 21st century</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=4" title="Edit section: 1990s and early 21st century">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The arrival of PSLV in 1990s became a major boost for the Indian space program. With the exception of its first flight in 1994 and two partial failures later, PSLV had a streak of more than 50 successful flights. PSLV enabled India to launch all of its <a href="/wiki/Low_Earth_orbit" title="Low Earth orbit">low Earth orbit</a> satellites, small payloads to GTO and hundreds of <a href="/wiki/List_of_foreign_satellites_launched_by_India" title="List of foreign satellites launched by India">foreign satellites</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[32]</a></sup> Along with the PSLV flights, development of a new rocket, a <a href="/wiki/Geosynchronous_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle" title="Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle">Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle</a> (GSLV) was going on. India tried to obtain upper-stage <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cryogenic_engine" title="Cryogenic engine">cryogenic engines</a> from Russia's <a href="/wiki/Glavkosmos" title="Glavkosmos">Glavkosmos</a> but was blocked by the US from doing so. As a result, <a href="/wiki/KVD-1" title="KVD-1">KVD-1</a> engines were imported from Russia under a new agreement which had limited success<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-flGSLVQuest_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-flGSLVQuest-35">[33]</a></sup> and a project to develop indigenous cryogenic technology was launched in 1994, taking two decades to reach fulfillment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GSLVGopalRaj_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-GSLVGopalRaj-36">[34]</a></sup> A new agreement was signed with Russia for seven <a href="/wiki/KVD-1" title="KVD-1">KVD-1</a> cryogenic stages and a ground mock-up stage with no technology transfer, instead of five cryogenic stages along with the technology and design in the earlier agreement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[35]</a></sup> These engines were used for the initial flights and were named GSLV Mk.1.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[36]</a></sup> ISRO was under US government sanctions between 6 May 1992 to 6 May 1994.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[37]</a></sup> After the United States refused to help India with <a href="/wiki/Global_Positioning_System" title="Global Positioning System">Global Positioning System</a> (GPS) technology during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kargil_war" title="Kargil war">Kargil war</a>, ISRO was prompted to develop its own satellite navigation system <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IRNSS" title="IRNSS">IRNSS</a> which it is now expanding further.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2003, when <a href="/wiki/Shenzhou_5" title="Shenzhou 5">China sent humans into space</a>, Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee" title="Atal Bihari Vajpayee">Atal Bihari Vajpayee</a> urged scientists to develop technologies to land humans on the Moon<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[39]</a></sup> and programs for lunar, planetary and crewed missions were started. ISRO launched <a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan-1" title="Chandrayaan-1">Chandrayaan-1</a> in 2008, purportedly the first probe to verify the presence of water on the Moon<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-THMoon_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-THMoon-42">[40]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Mars_Orbiter_Mission" title="Mars Orbiter Mission">Mars Orbiter Mission</a> in 2013, the first Asian spacecraft to enter Martian orbit; India was the first country to succeed at that on its first attempt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[41]</a></sup> Subsequently, the cryogenic upper stage for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GSLV" title="GSLV">GSLV</a> rocket became operational, making India the sixth country to have full launch capabilities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cryo14_8-1"><a href="#cite_note-Cryo14-8">[7]</a></sup> A new heavier-lift launcher <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GSLV_Mk_III" title="GSLV Mk III">GSLV Mk III</a> was introduced in 2014 for heavier satellites and future human space missions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[42]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agency_logo">Agency logo</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=5" title="Edit section: Agency logo">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>ISRO did not have an official logo until 2002. The one adopted consists of an orange arrow shooting upwards attached with two blue coloured satellite panels with the name of ISRO written in two sets of text, orange-coloured <a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a> on the left and blue-coloured English in the Prakrta typeface on the right.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SpaceIndia_Q2_2002_1-1"><a href="#cite_note-SpaceIndia_Q2_2002-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-logo_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-logo-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Goals_and_objectives">Goals and objectives</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=6" title="Edit section: Goals and objectives">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vikram_Sarabhai.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="478" data-file-width="353" decoding="async" height="244" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Vikram_Sarabhai.jpg/180px-Vikram_Sarabhai.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Vikram_Sarabhai.jpg/270px-Vikram_Sarabhai.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/63/Vikram_Sarabhai.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vikram_Sarabhai.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vikram_Sarabhai" title="Vikram Sarabhai">Vikram Sarabhai</a>, first chairperson of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/INCOSPAR" title="INCOSPAR">INCOSPAR</a>, ISRO's predecessor organization</div></div></div>
<p>ISRO is the national space agency of India for the purpose of all space-based applications like reconnaissance, communications and doing research. It undertakes the design and development of space rockets, satellites, explores upper atmosphere and deep space exploration missions. ISRO also has incubated its technologies in India's private space sector, boosting its growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-isro_aboutus_7-1"><a href="#cite_note-isro_aboutus-7">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERajagopalanPrasad20171–2_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERajagopalanPrasad20171–2-45">[43]</a></sup> Sarabhai said in 1969:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurleson2005136_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurleson2005136-46">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sarabhai_compilation_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sarabhai_compilation-48">[46]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>There are some who question the relevance of space activities in a developing nation. To us, there is no ambiguity of purpose. We do not have the fantasy of competing with the economically advanced nations in the exploration of the Moon or the planets or manned space-flight. But we are convinced that if we are to play a meaningful role nationally, and in the community of nations, we must be second to none in the application of advanced technologies to the real problems of man and society, which we find in our country. And we should note that the application of sophisticated technologies and methods of analysis to our problems is not to be confused with embarking on grandiose schemes, whose primary impact is for show rather than for progress measured in hard economic and social terms.</p></blockquote>
<p>The former <a href="/wiki/President_of_India" title="President of India">president of India</a>, <a href="/wiki/A._P._J._Abdul_Kalam" title="A. P. J. Abdul Kalam">A. P. J. Abdul Kalam</a>, said:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-apj_autobiography_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-apj_autobiography-49">[47]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Very many individuals with myopic vision questioned the relevance of space activities in a newly independent nation which was finding it difficult to feed its population. But neither Prime Minister Nehru nor Prof. Sarabhai had any ambiguity of purpose. Their vision was very clear: if Indians were to play a meaningful role in the community of nations, they must be second to none in the application of advanced technologies to their real-life problems. They had no intention of using it merely as a means of displaying our might.</p></blockquote>
<p>India's economic progress has made its space programme more visible and active as the country aims for greater <a href="/wiki/Self-sustainability" title="Self-sustainability">self-reliance</a> in space technology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newsweek1_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-newsweek1-50">[48]</a></sup> In 2008, India launched as many as 11<span class="nowrap"> </span>satellites, including nine from other countries, and went on to become the first nation to launch 10<span class="nowrap"> </span>satellites on one<span class="nowrap"> </span>rocket.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newsweek1_50-1"><a href="#cite_note-newsweek1-50">[48]</a></sup> ISRO has put into operation two major satellite systems: the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Satellite_System" title="Indian National Satellite System">Indian National Satellite System</a> (INSAT) for communication services, and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Remote_Sensing_Programme" title="Indian Remote Sensing Programme">Indian Remote Sensing Programme</a> (IRS) satellites for management of natural resources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Organisation_structure_and_facilities">Organisation structure and facilities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=7" title="Edit section: Organisation structure and facilities">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Department_of_Space_(India)_-_organization_chart.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1182" data-file-width="1758" decoding="async" height="195" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Department_of_Space_%28India%29_-_organization_chart.svg/290px-Department_of_Space_%28India%29_-_organization_chart.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Department_of_Space_%28India%29_-_organization_chart.svg/435px-Department_of_Space_%28India%29_-_organization_chart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Department_of_Space_%28India%29_-_organization_chart.svg/580px-Department_of_Space_%28India%29_-_organization_chart.svg.png 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Department_of_Space_(India)_-_organization_chart.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The organisational structure of the Indian <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Space" title="Department of Space">Department of Space</a></div></div></div>
<p>ISRO is managed by the DOS, which itself falls under the authority of the Space Commission and manages the following agencies and institutes:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>Indian Space Research Organisation</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Antrix_Corporation" title="Antrix Corporation">Antrix Corporation</a> – The marketing arm of ISRO, Bengaluru</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Physical_Research_Laboratory" title="Physical Research Laboratory">Physical Research Laboratory</a> (PRL), Ahmedabad</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/National_Atmospheric_Research_Laboratory" title="National Atmospheric Research Laboratory">National Atmospheric Research Laboratory</a> (NARL), Gadanki, <a href="/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh" title="Andhra Pradesh">Andhra Pradesh</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/NewSpace_India_Limited" title="NewSpace India Limited">NewSpace India Limited</a> – Commercial wing, Bengaluru</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/North-Eastern_Space_Applications_Centre" title="North-Eastern Space Applications Centre">North-Eastern Space Applications Centre</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[54]</a></sup> (NE-SAC), Umiam</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Space_Science_and_Technology" title="Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology">Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology</a> (IIST), Thiruvananthapuram – India's space university</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Research_facilities">Research facilities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=8" title="Edit section: Research facilities">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th style="width:18%;">Facility</th>
<th style="width:15%;">Location</th>
<th style="width:67%;">Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Vikram_Sarabhai_Space_Centre" title="Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre">Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre</a></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Thiruvananthapuram" title="Thiruvananthapuram">Thiruvananthapuram</a></td>
<td>The largest ISRO base is also the main technical centre and the venue for development of the <a href="/wiki/Satellite_Launch_Vehicle" title="Satellite Launch Vehicle">SLV-3</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ASLV" title="ASLV">ASLV</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PSLV" title="PSLV">PSLV</a> series.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup> The base supports TERLS and the <a href="/wiki/Rohini_(rocket_family)" title="Rohini (rocket family)">Rohini Sounding Rocket</a> programme.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup> It is also developing the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GSLV" title="GSLV">GSLV</a> series.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Liquid_Propulsion_Systems_Centre" title="Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre">Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre</a></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Thiruvananthapuram" title="Thiruvananthapuram">Thiruvananthapuram</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengaluru" title="Bengaluru">Bengaluru</a></td>
<td>The LPSC handles design, development, testing and implementation of liquid propulsion control packages, liquid stages and liquid engines for launch vehicles and satellites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup> The testing of these systems is largely conducted at <a href="/wiki/ISRO_Propulsion_Complex" title="ISRO Propulsion Complex">IPRC</a> at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahendragiri,_Tamil_Nadu" title="Mahendragiri, Tamil Nadu">Mahendragiri</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup> The LPSC, Bangalore also produces precision transducers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram414_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram414-58">[56]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Physical_Research_Laboratory" title="Physical Research Laboratory">Physical Research Laboratory</a></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Ahmedabad" title="Ahmedabad">Ahmedabad</a></td>
<td>Solar planetary physics, infrared astronomy, geo-cosmo physics, plasma physics, <a href="/wiki/Astrophysics" title="Astrophysics">astrophysics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Archaeology" title="Archaeology">archaeology</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hydrology" title="Hydrology">hydrology</a> are some of the branches of study at this institute.;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup> it also operates the observatory at <a href="/wiki/Udaipur" title="Udaipur">Udaipur</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-6"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Atmospheric_Radar_Laboratory" title="National Atmospheric Radar Laboratory">National Atmospheric Research Laboratory</a></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Tirupati" title="Tirupati">Tirupati</a></td>
<td>The NARL carries out fundamental and applied research in atmospheric and space sciences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[57]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Space_Applications_Centre" title="Space Applications Centre">Space Applications Centre</a></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Ahmedabad" title="Ahmedabad">Ahmedabad</a></td>
<td>The SAC deals with the various aspects of the practical use of space technology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-7"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup> Among the fields of research at the SAC are <a href="/wiki/Geodesy" title="Geodesy">geodesy</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Telecommunication" title="Telecommunication">satellite based telecommunications</a>, <a href="/wiki/Surveying" title="Surveying">surveying</a>, <a href="/wiki/Remote_sensing" title="Remote sensing">remote sensing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Meteorology" title="Meteorology">meteorology</a>, environment monitoring etc.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-8"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup> The SAC also operates the Delhi Earth Station, which is located in Delhi and is used for demonstration of various SATCOM experiments in addition to normal SATCOM operations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram415_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram415-60">[58]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/North-Eastern_Space_Applications_Centre" title="North-Eastern Space Applications Centre">North-Eastern Space Applications Centre</a></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Shillong" title="Shillong">Shillong</a></td>
<td>Providing developmental support to North East by undertaking specific application projects using remote sensing, GIS, satellite communication and conducting space science research.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[59]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Test_facilities">Test facilities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=9" title="Edit section: Test facilities">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th style="width:18%;">Facility</th>
<th style="width:15%;">Location</th>
<th style="width:67%;">Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/ISRO_Propulsion_Complex" title="ISRO Propulsion Complex">ISRO Propulsion Complex</a></td>
<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahendragiri,_Tamil_Nadu" title="Mahendragiri, Tamil Nadu">Mahendragiri</a></td>
<td>Formerly called LPSC-Mahendragiri, was declared a separate centre. It handles testing and assembly of liquid propulsion control packages, liquid engines, and stages for launch vehicles and satellites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-9"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Construction_and_launch_facilities">Construction and launch facilities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=10" title="Edit section: Construction and launch facilities">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th style="width:18%;">Facility</th>
<th style="width:15%;">Location</th>
<th style="width:67%;">Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/U_R_Rao_Satellite_Centre" title="U R Rao Satellite Centre">U R Rao Satellite Centre</a></td>
<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengaluru" title="Bengaluru">Bengaluru</a></td>
<td>The venue of eight successful spacecraft projects is also one of the main satellite technology bases of ISRO. The facility serves as a venue for implementing indigenous spacecraft in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-10"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup> The satellites <i>Aaryabhata</i>, <i>Bhaskara</i>, <i>APPLE</i>, and <i>IRS-1A</i> were built at this site, and the IRS and INSAT satellite series are presently under development here. This centre was formerly known as ISRO Satellite Centre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram414_58-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram414-58">[56]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Laboratory_for_Electro-Optics_Systems" title="Laboratory for Electro-Optics Systems">Laboratory for Electro-Optics Systems</a></td>
<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengaluru" title="Bengaluru">Bengaluru</a></td>
<td>The Unit of ISRO responsible for the development of altitude sensors for all satellites. The high precision optics for all cameras and payloads in all ISRO satellites are developed at this laboratory, located at Peenya Industrial Estate, Bangalore.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Satish_Dhawan_Space_Centre" title="Satish Dhawan Space Centre">Satish Dhawan Space Centre</a></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Sriharikota" title="Sriharikota">Sriharikota</a></td>
<td>With multiple sub-sites the Sriharikota island facility acts as a launching site for India's satellites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-11"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup> The Sriharikota facility is also the main launch base for India's sounding rockets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram414_58-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram414-58">[56]</a></sup> The centre is also home to India's largest Solid Propellant Space Booster Plant (SPROB) and houses the Static Test and Evaluation Complex (STEX).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram414_58-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram414-58">[56]</a></sup> The Second Vehicle Assembly Building (SVAB) at Sriharikota is being realised as an additional integration facility, with suitable interfacing to a second launch pad.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[60]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[61]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Thumba_Equatorial_Rocket_Launching_Station" title="Thumba Equatorial Rocket Launching Station">Thumba Equatorial Rocket Launching Station</a></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Thiruvananthapuram" title="Thiruvananthapuram">Thiruvananthapuram</a></td>
<td>TERLS is used to launch sounding rockets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[62]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tracking_and_control_facilities">Tracking and control facilities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=11" title="Edit section: Tracking and control facilities">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th style="width:18%;">Facility</th>
<th style="width:15%;">Location</th>
<th style="width:67%;">Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Indian_Deep_Space_Network" title="Indian Deep Space Network">Indian Deep Space Network (IDSN)</a></td>
<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengaluru" title="Bengaluru">Bengaluru</a></td>
<td>This network receives, processes, archives and distributes the spacecraft health data and payload data in real-time. It can track and monitor satellites up to very large distances, even beyond the <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">Moon</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[63]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/National_Remote_Sensing_Centre" title="National Remote Sensing Centre">National Remote Sensing Centre</a></td>
<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hyderabad,_Andhra_Pradesh" title="Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh">Hyderabad</a></td>
<td>The NRSC applies remote sensing to manage natural resources and study aerial surveying.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-12"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup> With centres at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Balanagar,_Ranga_Reddy" title="Balanagar, Ranga Reddy">Balanagar</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahbubnagar_district" title="Mahbubnagar district">Shadnagar</a> it also has training facilities at <a href="/wiki/Dehradun" title="Dehradun">Dehradun</a> acting as the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Remote_Sensing" title="Indian Institute of Remote Sensing">Indian Institute of Remote Sensing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-13"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/ISRO_Telemetry,_Tracking_and_Command_Network" title="ISRO Telemetry, Tracking and Command Network">ISRO Telemetry, Tracking and Command Network</a></td>
<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengaluru" title="Bengaluru">Bengaluru</a> (headquarters) and a number of ground stations throughout India and the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram415_60-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram415-60">[58]</a></sup></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Software_development" title="Software development">Software development</a>, ground operations, Tracking Telemetry and Command (TTC), and support is provided by this institution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-14"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup> ISTRAC has Tracking stations throughout the country and all over the world in <a href="/wiki/Port_Louis" title="Port Louis">Port Louis</a> (Mauritius), Bearslake (Russia), <a href="/wiki/Biak" title="Biak">Biak</a> (Indonesia) and <a href="/wiki/Brunei" title="Brunei">Brunei</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[64]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Master_Control_Facility" title="Master Control Facility">Master Control Facility</a></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Bhopal" title="Bhopal">Bhopal</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hassan,_India" title="Hassan, India">Hassan</a></td>
<td>Geostationary satellite orbit raising, payload testing, and in-orbit operations are performed at this facility.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram416_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram416-67">[65]</a></sup> The MCF has Earth stations and the Satellite Control Centre (SCC) for controlling satellites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram416_67-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram416-67">[65]</a></sup> A second MCF-like facility named 'MCF-B' is being constructed at Bhopal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram416_67-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram416-67">[65]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Space Situational Awareness Control Centre
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Peenya" title="Peenya">Peenya</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengaluru" title="Bengaluru">Bengaluru</a>
</td>
<td>A network of telescopes and radars are being set up under the Directorate of Space Situational Awareness and Management to monitor space debris and to safeguard space-based assets. The new facility will end ISRO's dependence on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norad" title="Norad">Norad</a>. The sophisticated multi-object tracking radar installed in Nellore, a radar in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NE_India" title="NE India">NE India</a> and telescopes in <a href="/wiki/Thiruvananthapuram" title="Thiruvananthapuram">Thiruvananthapuram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Abu" title="Mount Abu">Mount Abu</a> and North India will be part of this network.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[66]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[67]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_resource_development">Human resource development</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=12" title="Edit section: Human resource development">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th style="width:18%;">Facility</th>
<th style="width:15%;">Location</th>
<th style="width:67%;">Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Remote_Sensing" title="Indian Institute of Remote Sensing">Indian Institute of Remote Sensing</a> (IIRS)</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Dehradun" title="Dehradun">Dehradun</a></td>
<td>The Indian Institute of Remote Sensing (IIRS) is a premier training and educational institute set up for developing trained professionals (P.G. and PhD level) in the field of remote sensing, geoinformatics and GPS technology for natural resources, environmental and disaster management. IIRS is also executing many R&D projects on remote sensing and GIS for societal applications. IIRS also runs various outreach programs (Live & Interactive and e-learning) to build trained skilled human resources in the field of remote sensing and geospatial technologies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IIRSInfo_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-IIRSInfo-70">[68]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Space_Science_and_Technology" title="Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology">Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology</a> (IIST)</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Thiruvananthapuram" title="Thiruvananthapuram">Thiruvananthapuram</a></td>
<td>The institute offers undergraduate and graduate courses in Aerospace Engineering, Electronics and Communication Engineering (Avionics), and Engineering Physics. The students of the first three<span class="nowrap"> </span>batches of IIST were inducted into different <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISRO" title="ISRO">ISRO</a> centres.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[69]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Development_and_Educational_Communication_Unit" title="Development and Educational Communication Unit">Development and Educational Communication Unit</a></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Ahmedabad" title="Ahmedabad">Ahmedabad</a></td>
<td>The centre works for education, research, and training, mainly in conjunction with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/INSAT" title="INSAT">INSAT</a> programme.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOjha142_57-15"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOjha142-57">[55]</a></sup> The main activities carried out at DECU include GRAMSAT and <a href="/wiki/GSAT-3" title="GSAT-3">EDUSAT</a> projects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram414_58-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram414-58">[56]</a></sup> The Training and Development Communication Channel (TDCC) also falls under the operational control of the DECU.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram415_60-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram415-60">[58]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Space Technology Incubation Centres (S-TICs) at:
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Dr._B._R._Ambedkar_National_Institute_of_Technology_Jalandhar" title="Dr. B. R. Ambedkar National Institute of Technology Jalandhar">Dr. B. R. Ambedkar National Institute of Technology Jalandhar</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Maulana_Azad_National_Institute_of_Technology" title="Maulana Azad National Institute of Technology">Maulana Azad National Institute of Technology</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Technology_Agartala" title="National Institute of Technology Agartala">National Institute of Technology Agartala</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Technology,_Rourkela" title="National Institute of Technology, Rourkela">National Institute of Technology, Rourkela</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[70]</a></sup></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Visvesvaraya_National_Institute_of_Technology" title="Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology">Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[71]</a></sup></li></ul>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Agartala" title="Agartala">Agartala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bhopal" title="Bhopal">Bhopal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jalandhar" title="Jalandhar">Jalandhar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nagpur" title="Nagpur">Nagpur</a> <a href="/wiki/Rourkela" title="Rourkela">Rourkela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tiruchirappalli" title="Tiruchirappalli">Tiruchirappalli</a>
</td>
<td>The S-TICs opened at premier technical universities in India to promote startups to build applications and products in tandem with the industry and would be used for future space missions. The S-TIC will bring the industry, academia and ISRO under one umbrella to contribute towards research and development (R&D) initiatives relevant to the Indian Space Programme.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1a_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1a-74">[72]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Space Innovation Centre at:
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Veer_Surendra_Sai_University_of_Technology" title="Veer Surendra Sai University of Technology">Veer Surendra Sai University of Technology</a></li></ul>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Burla,_India" title="Burla, India">Burla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sambalpur" title="Sambalpur">Sambalpur</a>
</td>
<td>In line with its ongoing effort to promote R&D in space technology through industry as well as academia, ISRO in collaboration with Veer Surendra Sai University of Technology (VSSUT), Burla, Sambalpur, Odisha, has set up Veer Surendra Sai Space Innovation Centre (VSSSIC) within its campus at Sambalpur. The objective of its Space Innovation Research Lab is to promote and encourage the students in research and development in the area of space science and technology at VSSUT and other institutes within this region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[73]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[74]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Regional Academy Centre for Space (RAC-S) at:
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Banaras_Hindu_University" title="Banaras Hindu University">Banaras Hindu University</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gauhati_University" title="Gauhati University">Gauhati University</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kurukshetra_University" title="Kurukshetra University">Kurukshetra University</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Malaviya_National_Institute_of_Technology,_Jaipur" title="Malaviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur">Malaviya National Institute of Technology</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Technology_Karnataka" title="National Institute of Technology Karnataka">National Institute of Technology Karnataka</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Technology,_Patna" title="National Institute of Technology, Patna">National Institute of Technology Patna</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Technology_(BHU)_Varanasi" title="Indian Institute of Technology (BHU) Varanasi">Indian Institute of Technology (BHU) Varanasi</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[75]</a></sup></li></ul>
<p><br/>
</p>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Varanasi" title="Varanasi">Varanasi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guwahati" title="Guwahati">Guwahati</a>,  <a href="/wiki/Kurukshetra" title="Kurukshetra">Kurukshetra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jaipur" title="Jaipur">Jaipur</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mangaluru" title="Mangaluru">Mangaluru</a>, <a href="/wiki/Patna" title="Patna">Patna</a>
</td>
<td>All these centres are set up in tier-2 cities to create awareness, strengthen academic collaboration and act as incubators for space technology, space science and space applications. The activities of RAC-S will maximise the use of research potential, infrastructure, expertise, experience and facilitate capacity building.

<h3><span id="Antrix_Corporation_Limited_.28Commercial_Wing.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Antrix_Corporation_Limited_(Commercial_Wing)">Antrix Corporation Limited (Commercial Wing)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=13" title="Edit section: Antrix Corporation Limited (Commercial Wing)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Antrix_Corporation" title="Antrix Corporation">Antrix Corporation</a></div>
<p>Set up as the marketing arm of ISRO, <a href="/wiki/Antrix_Corporation" title="Antrix Corporation">Antrix</a>'s job is to promote products, services and technology developed by ISRO.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AntrixISRO_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-AntrixISRO-78">[76]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AntrixNewChief_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-AntrixNewChief-79">[77]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="NewSpace_India_Limited_.28Commercial_Wing.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="NewSpace_India_Limited_(Commercial_Wing)">NewSpace India Limited (Commercial Wing)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=14" title="Edit section: NewSpace India Limited (Commercial Wing)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/NewSpace_India_Limited" title="NewSpace India Limited">NewSpace India Limited</a></div>
<p>Set up for marketing spin-off technologies, tech transfers through industry interface and scale up industry participation in the space programmes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Space_Technology_Incubation_Centre">Space Technology Incubation Centre</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=15" title="Edit section: Space Technology Incubation Centre">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>ISRO has opened Space Technology Incubation Centres (S-TIC) at premier technical universities in India which will incubate startups to build applications and products in tandem with the industry and would be used for future space missions. The S-TIC will bring the industry, academia and ISRO under one umbrella to contribute towards research and development (R&D) initiatives relevant to the Indian Space Programme. S-TICs are at the <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Technology_Agartala" title="National Institute of Technology Agartala">National Institute of Technology, Agartala</a> serving for east region, <a href="/wiki/Dr._B._R._Ambedkar_National_Institute_of_Technology_Jalandhar" title="Dr. B. R. Ambedkar National Institute of Technology Jalandhar">National Institute of Technology, Jalandhar</a> for the north region, and the <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Technology,_Tiruchirappalli" title="National Institute of Technology, Tiruchirappalli">National Institute of Technology, Tiruchirappalli</a> for the south region of India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1a_74-1"><a href="#cite_note-:1a-74">[72]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Advance_Space_Research_Group">Advance Space Research Group</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=16" title="Edit section: Advance Space Research Group">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Like NASA funded <a href="/wiki/Jet_Propulsion_Laboratory" title="Jet Propulsion Laboratory">Jet Propulsion Laboratory</a> (JPL) managed by <a href="/wiki/California_Institute_of_Technology" title="California Institute of Technology">California Institute of Technology</a> (Caltech), ISRO with <a href="/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Space_Science_and_Technology" title="Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology">Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology</a> (IIST) implemented a joint working framework in 2021 in which an Empowered Overseeing Committee (EOC) under Capacity Building Programme Office (CBPO) of ISRO located in Bengaluru will approve all short, medium and long term space research projects of common interest. In return, an Advance Space Research Group (ASRG) formed at IIST under the guidance of EOC will have full access to ISRO facilities. The primary aim is to transform IIST into a premier space research and engineering institute by 2028–2030 that can lead future space exploration missions of ISRO.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[79]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[80]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Directorate_of_Space_Situational_Awareness_and_Management">Directorate of Space Situational Awareness and Management</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=17" title="Edit section: Directorate of Space Situational Awareness and Management">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>To reduce dependency on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_American_Aerospace_Defense_Command" title="North American Aerospace Defense Command">North America Aerospace Defense Command</a> (NORAD) for space situational awareness and protect the civilian and military assets, ISRO is setting up telescopes and radars in four locations to cover each direction. <a href="/wiki/Leh" title="Leh">Leh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Abu" title="Mount Abu">Mount Abu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ponmudi" title="Ponmudi">Ponmudi</a> were selected to station the telescopes and radars that will cover North, West and South of Indian territory. The last one will be in <a href="/wiki/Northeast_India" title="Northeast India">Northeast India</a> to cover the entire eastern region. <a href="/wiki/Satish_Dhawan_Space_Centre" title="Satish Dhawan Space Centre">Satish Dhawan Space Centre</a> at Sriharikota already supports Multi-Object Tracking Radar (MOTR).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[81]</a></sup> All the telescopes and radars will come under Directorate of Space Situational Awareness and Management (DSSAM) in Bengaluru. It will collect tracking data on inactive satellites and will also perform research on active debris removal, space debris modelling and mitigation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[82]</a></sup>
</p><p>For  early warning, ISRO began a ₹400 crore (4 billion; US$53 million) project called Network for Space Object Tracking and Analysis (NETRA). It will help the country track <a href="/wiki/Atmospheric_entry" title="Atmospheric entry">atmospheric entry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Intercontinental_ballistic_missile" title="Intercontinental ballistic missile">intercontinental ballistic missile</a> (ICBM), <a href="/wiki/Anti-satellite_weapon" title="Anti-satellite weapon">anti-satellite weapon</a> and other space-based attacks. All the radars and telescopes will be connected through NETRA. The system will support <a href="/wiki/Remote_work" title="Remote work">remote</a> and scheduled operations. NETRA will follow the <a href="/wiki/Inter-Agency_Space_Debris_Coordination_Committee" title="Inter-Agency Space Debris Coordination Committee">Inter-Agency Space Debris Coordination Committee</a> (IASDCC) and <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Office_for_Outer_Space_Affairs" title="United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs">United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs</a> (UNOSA) guidelines. The objective of NETRA is to track objects at a distance of 36,000 kilometres (22,000 mi) in GTO.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[83]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>India signed a <a href="/wiki/Memorandum_of_understanding" title="Memorandum of understanding">memorandum of understanding</a> on the Space Situational Awareness Data Sharing Pact with the US in April 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[85]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[86]</a></sup> It will enable <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Space" title="Department of Space">Department of Space</a> to collaborate with the <a href="/wiki/Combined_Space_Operations_Center" title="Combined Space Operations Center">Combined Space Operation Center</a> (CSpOC) to protect the space-based assets of both nations from natural and man-made threats.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[87]</a></sup> On 11 July 2022, ISRO System for Safe and Sustainable Space Operations Management (IS4OM) at Space Situational Awareness Control Centre, in Peenya was inaugurated by <a href="/wiki/Jitendra_Singh_(politician,_born_1956)" title="Jitendra Singh (politician, born 1956)">Jitender Singh</a>. It will help provide information on on-orbit collision, fragmentation, atmospheric re-entry risk, space-based strategic information, hazardous asteroids, and space weather forecast. IS4OM will safeguard all the operational space assets, identify and monitor other operational spacecrafts with close approaches which have overpasses over <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a> and those which conduct intentional manoeuvres with suspicious motives or seek re-entry within <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_facilities">Other facilities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=18" title="Edit section: Other facilities">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>

<li><a href="/wiki/Human_Space_Flight_Centre" title="Human Space Flight Centre">Human Space Flight Centre</a> (HSFC), Bengaluru</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Integrated_Space_Cell" title="Integrated Space Cell">Integrated Space Cell</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Inter-University_Centre_for_Astronomy_and_Astrophysics" title="Inter-University Centre for Astronomy and Astrophysics">Inter University Centre for Astronomy and Astrophysics (IUCAA)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/ISRO_Inertial_Systems_Unit" title="ISRO Inertial Systems Unit">ISRO Inertial Systems Unit (IISU)</a> – Thiruvananthapuram</li>
