<li><a href="/wiki/National_Remote_Sensing_Centre" title="National Remote Sensing Centre">Regional Remote Sensing Service Centres</a> (RRSSC)</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="General_satellite_programmes">General satellite programmes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=19" title="Edit section: General satellite programmes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Indian_satellites" title="List of Indian satellites">List of Indian satellites</a></div><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Insat-1B.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1824" data-file-width="1824" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Insat-1B.jpg/220px-Insat-1B.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Insat-1B.jpg/330px-Insat-1B.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Insat-1B.jpg/440px-Insat-1B.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Insat-1B.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Insat" title="Insat">INSAT-1B</a></div></div></div>
<p>Since the launch of <a href="/wiki/Aryabhata_(satellite)" title="Aryabhata (satellite)">Aryabhata</a> in 1975,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Aryabhatta_15-2"><a href="#cite_note-Aryabhatta-15">[13]</a></sup> a number of satellite series and constellations have been deployed by Indian and foreign launchers. At present, ISRO operates one of the largest constellations of active communication and earth imaging satellites for military and civilian uses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IRSSaga_33-1"><a href="#cite_note-IRSSaga-33">[31]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_IRS_series">The IRS series</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=20" title="Edit section: The IRS series">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_Remote_Sensing_satellite" title="Indian Remote Sensing satellite">Indian Remote Sensing satellite</a></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_Remote_Sensing_satellite" title="Indian Remote Sensing satellite">Indian Remote Sensing satellites</a> (IRS) are India's earth observation satellites. They are the largest collection of remote sensing satellites for civilian use in operation today, provideing remote sensing services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IRSSaga_33-2"><a href="#cite_note-IRSSaga-33">[31]</a></sup> All the satellites are placed in polar <a href="/wiki/Sun-synchronous_orbit" title="Sun-synchronous orbit">Sun-synchronous orbit</a> (except <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GISAT" title="GISAT">GISATs</a>) and provide data in a variety of spatial, spectral and temporal resolutions to enable several programmes to be undertaken relevant to national development. The initial versions are composed of the 1 (<a href="/wiki/IRS-1A" title="IRS-1A">A</a>, <a href="/wiki/IRS-1B" title="IRS-1B">B</a>, <a href="/wiki/IRS-1C" title="IRS-1C">C</a>, <a href="/wiki/IRS-1D" title="IRS-1D">D</a>) nomenclature while the later versions were divided into sub-classes named based on their functioning and uses including <a href="/wiki/Oceansat" title="Oceansat">Oceansat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cartosat" title="Cartosat">Cartosat</a>, <a href="/wiki/HySIS" title="HySIS">HySIS</a>, <a href="/wiki/EMISAT" title="EMISAT">EMISAT</a> and ResourceSat etc. Their names were unified under the prefix "EOS" regardless of functioning in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[89]</a></sup> They support a wide range of applications including optical, radar and electronic <a href="/wiki/Reconnaissance" title="Reconnaissance">reconnaissance</a> for Indian agencies, city planning, oceanography and environmental studies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IRSSaga_33-3"><a href="#cite_note-IRSSaga-33">[31]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_INSAT_series">The INSAT series</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=21" title="Edit section: The INSAT series">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Satellite_System" title="Indian National Satellite System">Indian National Satellite System</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:STS008-44-611.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/STS008-44-611.jpg/220px-STS008-44-611.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/STS008-44-611.jpg/330px-STS008-44-611.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/STS008-44-611.jpg/440px-STS008-44-611.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:STS008-44-611.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>INSAT-1B satellite: The broadcasting sector in India is highly dependent on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/INSAT" title="INSAT">INSAT</a> system.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Satellite_System" title="Indian National Satellite System">Indian National Satellite System</a> (INSAT) is the country's telecommunication system. It is a series of multipurpose <a href="/wiki/Geosynchronous_satellite" title="Geosynchronous satellite">geostationary satellites</a> built and launched by ISRO to satisfy the telecommunications, broadcasting, meteorology and search-and-rescue needs. Since the introduction of the first one in 1983, INSAT has become the largest domestic communication system in the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific" title="Asia-Pacific">Asia-Pacific</a> Region. It is a joint venture of DOS, the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Telecommunications" title="Department of Telecommunications">Department of Telecommunications</a>, <a href="/wiki/India_Meteorological_Department" title="India Meteorological Department">India Meteorological Department</a>, <a href="/wiki/All_India_Radio" title="All India Radio">All India Radio</a> and <a href="/wiki/Doordarshan" title="Doordarshan">Doordarshan</a>. The overall coordination and management of INSAT system rests with the Secretary-level INSAT Coordination Committee.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INSAT_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-INSAT-92">[90]</a></sup> The nomenclature of the series was changed to "<a href="/wiki/GSAT" title="GSAT">GSAT</a>" from "INSAT", then further changed to "CMS" from 2020 onwards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-THCMS_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-THCMS-93">[91]</a></sup> These satellites have been used by the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Armed_Forces" title="Indian Armed Forces">Indian Armed Forces</a> as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[92]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[93]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GSAT-9" title="GSAT-9">GSAT-9</a> or "SAARC Satellite" provides communication services for India's smaller neighbors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Gagan_Satellite_Navigation_System">Gagan Satellite Navigation System</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=22" title="Edit section: Gagan Satellite Navigation System">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GPS-aided_geo-augmented_navigation" title="GPS-aided geo-augmented navigation">GPS-aided geo-augmented navigation</a></div>
<p>The Ministry of Civil Aviation has decided to implement an indigenous Satellite-Based Regional GPS Augmentation System also known as <a href="/wiki/GNSS_augmentation" title="GNSS augmentation">Space-Based Augmentation System (SBAS)</a> as part of the Satellite-Based Communications, Navigation, Surveillance and Air Traffic Management plan for civil aviation. The Indian SBAS system has been given the acronym <a href="/wiki/GPS-aided_GEO_augmented_navigation" title="GPS-aided GEO augmented navigation">GAGAN – GPS Aided GEO Augmented Navigation</a>. A national plan for satellite navigation including implementation of a Technology Demonstration System (TDS) over Indian airspace as a <a href="/wiki/Proof_of_concept" title="Proof of concept">proof of concept</a> has been prepared jointly by <a href="/wiki/Airports_Authority_of_India" title="Airports Authority of India">Airports Authority of India</a> and ISRO. The TDS was completed during 2007 with the installation of eight Indian Reference Stations at different airports linked to the Master Control Centre located near <a href="/wiki/Bangalore" title="Bangalore">Bangalore</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[95]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Navigation_with_Indian_Constellation_.28NavIC.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Navigation_with_Indian_Constellation_(NavIC)">Navigation with Indian Constellation (NavIC)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=23" title="Edit section: Navigation with Indian Constellation (NavIC)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Indian_Regional_Navigation_Satellite_System" title="Indian Regional Navigation Satellite System">Indian Regional Navigation Satellite System</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:IRNSS_Coverage_Polygon.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="638" data-file-width="975" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/IRNSS_Coverage_Polygon.png/220px-IRNSS_Coverage_Polygon.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/IRNSS_Coverage_Polygon.png/330px-IRNSS_Coverage_Polygon.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/IRNSS_Coverage_Polygon.png/440px-IRNSS_Coverage_Polygon.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:IRNSS_Coverage_Polygon.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Coverage of the IRNSS in blue, as of 2020</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Indian_Regional_Navigation_Satellite_System" title="Indian Regional Navigation Satellite System">IRNSS</a> with an operational name <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NavIC" title="NavIC">NavIC</a> is an independent regional navigation satellite system developed by India. It is designed to provide accurate position information service to users in India as well as the region extending up to 1,500 km (930 mi) from its borders, which is its primary service area. IRNSS provides two types of services, namely, Standard Positioning Service (SPS) and Restricted Service (RS), providing a position accuracy of better than 20 m (66 ft) in the primary service area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[96]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_satellites">Other satellites</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=24" title="Edit section: Other satellites">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable plainlinks" role="note">This is a <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Lists#Incomplete_lists" title="Wikipedia:WikiProject Lists">dynamic list</a> and may never be able to satisfy particular standards for completeness. You can help by <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit">adding missing items</a> with <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources">reliable sources</a>.</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Kalpana-1" title="Kalpana-1">Kalpana-1</a> (MetSat-1) was ISRO's first dedicated meteorological satellite.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[98]</a></sup> Indo-French satellite <a href="/wiki/SARAL" title="SARAL">SARAL</a> on 25 February 2013. SARAL (or "Satellite with ARgos and AltiKa") is a cooperative altimetry technology mission, used for monitoring the oceans' surface and sea levels. AltiKa measures ocean surface topography with an accuracy of 8 mm (0.31 in), compared to 2.5 cm (0.98 in) on average using altimeters, and with a spatial resolution of 2 km (1.2 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iex25f13_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-iex25f13-101">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Launch_vehicles">Launch vehicles</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=25" title="Edit section: Launch vehicles">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Indian_carrier_rockets.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="486" data-file-width="550" decoding="async" height="265" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Indian_carrier_rockets.svg/300px-Indian_carrier_rockets.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Indian_carrier_rockets.svg/450px-Indian_carrier_rockets.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Indian_carrier_rockets.svg/600px-Indian_carrier_rockets.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Indian_carrier_rockets.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Comparison of Indian carrier rockets. Left to right: <a href="/wiki/Satellite_Launch_Vehicle" title="Satellite Launch Vehicle">SLV</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ASLV" title="ASLV">ASLV</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PSLV" title="PSLV">PSLV</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GSLV" title="GSLV">GSLV</a>, <a href="/wiki/LVM_3" title="LVM 3">LVM 3</a></div></div></div>
<p>During the 1960s and 1970s, India initiated its own launch vehicles owing to geopolitical and economic considerations. In the 1960s–1970s, the country developed a sounding rocket, and by the 1980s, research had yielded the Satellite Launch Vehicle-3 and the more advanced <a href="/wiki/Augmented_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle" title="Augmented Satellite Launch Vehicle">Augmented Satellite Launch Vehicle</a> (ASLV), complete with operational supporting infrastructure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGuptaSureshSivan20071697_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGuptaSureshSivan20071697-103">[101]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Satellite_Launch_Vehicle">Satellite Launch Vehicle</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=26" title="Edit section: Satellite Launch Vehicle">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Satellite_Launch_Vehicle" title="Satellite Launch Vehicle">Satellite Launch Vehicle</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stamp_of_India_-_1981_-_Colnect_505879_-_Launch_of_Rohini_Satellite.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="350" data-file-width="240" decoding="async" height="321" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Stamp_of_India_-_1981_-_Colnect_505879_-_Launch_of_Rohini_Satellite.jpeg/220px-Stamp_of_India_-_1981_-_Colnect_505879_-_Launch_of_Rohini_Satellite.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ee/Stamp_of_India_-_1981_-_Colnect_505879_-_Launch_of_Rohini_Satellite.jpeg 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stamp_of_India_-_1981_-_Colnect_505879_-_Launch_of_Rohini_Satellite.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Stamp depicting SLV-3 D1 carrying <a href="/wiki/Rohini_(satellite)" title="Rohini (satellite)">RS-D1</a> satellite to orbit</div></div></div>
<p>The Satellite Launch Vehicle (known as SLV-3) was the first space rocket to be developed by India. The initial launch in 1979 was a failure followed by a successful launch in 1980 making India the sixth country in world with orbital launch capability. The development of bigger rockets began afterwards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SLVFlipbook_26-1"><a href="#cite_note-SLVFlipbook-26">[24]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Augmented_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle">Augmented Satellite Launch Vehicle</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=27" title="Edit section: Augmented Satellite Launch Vehicle">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Augmented_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle" title="Augmented Satellite Launch Vehicle">Augmented Satellite Launch Vehicle</a></div>
<p>Augmented or Advanced Satellite Launch Vehicle (ASLV) was another small launch vehicle released in 1980s to develop technologies required to place satellites into <a href="/wiki/Geostationary_orbit" title="Geostationary orbit">geostationary orbit</a>. ISRO did not have adequate funds to develop ASLV and PSLV at once. Since ASLV suffered repeated failures, it was dropped in favour of a new project.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bharat-rakshak.com_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-bharat-rakshak.com-104">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ITASLV_30-1"><a href="#cite_note-ITASLV-30">[28]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Polar_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle">Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=28" title="Edit section: Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Polar_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle" title="Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle">Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PSLV-C11_launch2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1181" data-file-width="787" decoding="async" height="330" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/PSLV-C11_launch2.jpg/220px-PSLV-C11_launch2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/PSLV-C11_launch2.jpg/330px-PSLV-C11_launch2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/PSLV-C11_launch2.jpg/440px-PSLV-C11_launch2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PSLV-C11_launch2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>PSLV-C11 lifts off carrying <a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan-1" title="Chandrayaan-1">Chandrayaan-1</a>, first Indian mission to the moon.</div></div></div>
<p>Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle or PSLV is the first <a href="/wiki/Medium-lift_launch_vehicle" title="Medium-lift launch vehicle">medium-lift launch vehicle</a> from India which enabled India to launch all its remote-sensing satellites into <a href="/wiki/Sun-synchronous_orbit" title="Sun-synchronous orbit">Sun-synchronous orbit</a>. PSLV had a failure in its maiden launch in 1993. Besides two other partial failures, PSLV has become the primary workhorse for ISRO with more than 50 launches placing hundreds of Indian and foreign satellites into orbit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[103]</a></sup>

<h3><span id="Geosynchronous_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle_.28GSLV.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Geosynchronous_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle_(GSLV)">Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle (GSLV)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=29" title="Edit section: Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle (GSLV)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geosynchronous_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle" title="Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle">Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GSLV-F08_Liftoff_5.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3800" data-file-width="2533" decoding="async" height="330" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/GSLV-F08_Liftoff_5.jpg/220px-GSLV-F08_Liftoff_5.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/GSLV-F08_Liftoff_5.jpg/330px-GSLV-F08_Liftoff_5.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/GSLV-F08_Liftoff_5.jpg/440px-GSLV-F08_Liftoff_5.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GSLV-F08_Liftoff_5.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>GSLV-F08 launches <a href="/wiki/GSAT-6A" title="GSAT-6A">GSAT-6A</a> into <a href="/wiki/Geostationary_transfer_orbit" title="Geostationary transfer orbit">geostationary transfer orbit</a> (2018).</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Geosynchronous_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle" title="Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle">Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle</a> was envisaged in 1990s to transfer significant payloads to geostationary orbit. ISRO initially had a great problem realising GSLV as the development of <a href="/wiki/CE-7.5" title="CE-7.5">CE-7.5</a> in India took a decade. The US had blocked India from obtaining cryogenic technology from Russia, leading India to develop its own cryogenic engines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-flGSLVQuest_35-1"><a href="#cite_note-flGSLVQuest-35">[33]</a></sup>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Launch_Vehicle_Mark-3">Launch Vehicle Mark-3</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=30" title="Edit section: Launch Vehicle Mark-3">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/LVM_3" title="LVM 3">LVM 3</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GSLV-Mk_III-D1_being_moved_from_Vehicle_Assembly_Building_to_second_launch_pad.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3447" data-file-width="2583" decoding="async" height="294" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/GSLV-Mk_III-D1_being_moved_from_Vehicle_Assembly_Building_to_second_launch_pad.jpg/220px-GSLV-Mk_III-D1_being_moved_from_Vehicle_Assembly_Building_to_second_launch_pad.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/GSLV-Mk_III-D1_being_moved_from_Vehicle_Assembly_Building_to_second_launch_pad.jpg/330px-GSLV-Mk_III-D1_being_moved_from_Vehicle_Assembly_Building_to_second_launch_pad.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/GSLV-Mk_III-D1_being_moved_from_Vehicle_Assembly_Building_to_second_launch_pad.jpg/440px-GSLV-Mk_III-D1_being_moved_from_Vehicle_Assembly_Building_to_second_launch_pad.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GSLV-Mk_III-D1_being_moved_from_Vehicle_Assembly_Building_to_second_launch_pad.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>GSLV Mk III D1 being moved from assembly building to the launch pad</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GSLV_Mk_III_Lift_Off_3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1232" data-file-width="820" decoding="async" height="331" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/GSLV_Mk_III_Lift_Off_3.jpg/220px-GSLV_Mk_III_Lift_Off_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/GSLV_Mk_III_Lift_Off_3.jpg/330px-GSLV_Mk_III_Lift_Off_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/GSLV_Mk_III_Lift_Off_3.jpg/440px-GSLV_Mk_III_Lift_Off_3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GSLV_Mk_III_Lift_Off_3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/LVM_3" title="LVM 3">LVM 3</a> lifts off on its first orbital launch, carrying <a href="/wiki/GSAT-19" title="GSAT-19">GSAT-19</a> into <a href="/wiki/Geostationary_transfer_orbit" title="Geostationary transfer orbit">geostationary transfer orbit</a> (2017).</div></div></div>
<p>Launch Vehicle Mark-3 (LVM 3), previously known as GSLV Mk3, is the heaviest rocket in operational service with ISRO. Equipped with a more powerful cryogenic engine and boosters than GSLV, it has significantly higher playload capacity and allows India to launch all its communication satellites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[104]</a></sup> LVM3 is expected to carry <a href="/wiki/Gaganyaan" title="Gaganyaan">India's first crewed mission to space</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[105]</a></sup> and will be the testbed for <a href="/wiki/SCE-200" title="SCE-200">SCE-200</a> engine which will power India's <a href="/wiki/Heavy-lift_launch_vehicle" title="Heavy-lift launch vehicle">heavy lift rockets</a> in future.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Episode_90_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-Episode_90-108">[106]</a></sup>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="SSLV">SSLV</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=31" title="Edit section: SSLV">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Small_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle" title="Small Satellite Launch Vehicle">Small Satellite Launch Vehicle</a></div>
<p>The <b>Small Satellite Launch Vehicle</b> (<b>SSLV</b>) is a <a href="/wiki/Small-lift_launch_vehicle" title="Small-lift launch vehicle">small-lift launch vehicle</a> developed by the ISRO with payload capacity to deliver 500 kg (1,100 lb) to <a href="/wiki/Low_Earth_orbit" title="Low Earth orbit">low Earth orbit</a> (500 km (310 mi)) or 300 kg (660 lb) to <a href="/wiki/Sun-synchronous_orbit" title="Sun-synchronous orbit">Sun-synchronous orbit</a> (500 km (310 mi))<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SSLV_UMv2_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-SSLV_UMv2-111">[109]</a></sup> for launching small satellites, with the capability to support multiple orbital drop-offs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[110]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1b_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1b-113">[111]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DoS_20190118_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-DoS_20190118-114">[112]</a></sup>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_Spaceflight_Programme">Human Spaceflight Programme</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=32" title="Edit section: Human Spaceflight Programme">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Indian_Human_Spaceflight_Programme" title="Indian Human Spaceflight Programme">Indian Human Spaceflight Programme</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gaganyaan" title="Gaganyaan">Gaganyaan</a></div>
<p>The first proposal to send humans into space was discussed by ISRO in 2006, leading to work on the required infrastructure and spacecraft.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[114]</a></sup> The trials for crewed space missions began in 2007 with the 600-kilogram (1,300 lb) <a href="/wiki/Space_Capsule_Recovery_Experiment" title="Space Capsule Recovery Experiment">Space Capsule Recovery Experiment</a> (SRE), launched using the <a href="/wiki/Polar_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle" title="Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle">Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle</a> (PSLV) rocket, and safely returned to earth 12 days later.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2009, the Indian Space Research Organisation proposed a budget of <span class="nowrap"><span style="white-space: nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Indian_rupee" title="Indian rupee">₹</a></span>124 <a href="/wiki/1,000,000,000" title="1,000,000,000">billion</a></span> (equivalent to <span style="white-space: nowrap">₹</span>260 billion or US$3.3 billion in 2020) for its human spaceflight programme. An uncrewed demonstration flight was expected after seven years from the final approval and a crewed mission was to be launched after seven years of funding.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[116]</a></sup> A crewed mission initially was not a priority and left on the backburner for several years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[117]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Crew_Module_Atmospheric_Re-entry_Experiment" title="Crew Module Atmospheric Re-entry Experiment">space capsule recovery experiment</a> in 2014<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[119]</a></sup> and a pad abort test in 2018<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[120]</a></sup> were followed by Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">Narendra Modi</a>'s announcement in his 2018 <a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(India)" title="Independence Day (India)">Independence Day</a> address that India will send astronauts into space by 2022 on the new <i><a href="/wiki/Gaganyaan" title="Gaganyaan">Gaganyaan</a></i> spacecraft.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[121]</a></sup> To date, ISRO has developed most of the technologies needed, such as the crew module and crew escape system, space food, and life support systems. The project would cost less than <span style="white-space: nowrap">₹</span>100 billion (US$1.3 billion) and would include sending two or three Indians to space, at an altitude of 300–400 km (190–250 mi), for at least seven days, using a GSLV Mk-III launch vehicle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[122]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[123]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Astronaut_training_and_other_facilities">Astronaut training and other facilities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=33" title="Edit section: Astronaut training and other facilities">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The newly established <a href="/wiki/Human_Space_Flight_Centre" title="Human Space Flight Centre">Human Space Flight Centre</a> (HSFC) will coordinate the IHSF campaign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[124]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[125]</a></sup> ISRO will set up an astronaut training centre in Bangalore to prepare personnel for flights in the crewed vehicle. It will use simulation facilities to train the selected astronauts in rescue and recovery operations and survival in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Microgravity" title="Microgravity">microgravity</a>, and will undertake studies of the radiation environment of space. ISRO had to build <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-G_training" title="High-G training">centrifuges</a> to prepare astronauts for the acceleration phase of the launch. Existing launch facilities at <a href="/wiki/Satish_Dhawan_Space_Centre" title="Satish Dhawan Space Centre">Satish Dhawan Space Centre</a> will have to be upgraded for the Indian human spaceflight campaign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[126]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Human_Space_Flight_Centre" title="Human Space Flight Centre">Human Space Flight Centre</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Glavcosmos" title="Glavcosmos">Glavcosmos</a> signed an agreement on 1 July 2019 for the selection, support, medical examination and space training of Indian astronauts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[127]</a></sup> An ISRO Technical Liaison Unit (ITLU) was to be set up in <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a> to facilitate the development of some key technologies and establishment of special facilities which are essential to support life in space.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[128]</a></sup> Four <a href="/wiki/Indian_Air_Force" title="Indian Air Force">Indian Air Force</a> personnel finished training at <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Gagarin_Cosmonaut_Training_Center" title="Yuri Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Center">Yuri Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Center</a> in March 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Trainingok_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-Trainingok-131">[129]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Crewed_spacecraft">Crewed spacecraft</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=34" title="Edit section: Crewed spacecraft">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Gaganyaan" title="Gaganyaan">Gaganyaan</a></div>
<p>ISRO is working towards an <a href="/wiki/Orbital_spaceflight" title="Orbital spaceflight">orbital</a> crewed spacecraft that can operate for seven days in <a href="/wiki/Low_Earth_orbit" title="Low Earth orbit">low Earth orbit</a>. The spacecraft, called <i><a href="/wiki/Gaganyaan" title="Gaganyaan">Gaganyaan</a></i>, will be the basis of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Human_Spaceflight_Programme" title="Indian Human Spaceflight Programme">Indian Human Spaceflight Programme</a>. The spacecraft is being developed to carry up to three people, and a planned upgraded version will be equipped with a rendezvous and docking capability. In its first crewed mission, ISRO's largely autonomous 3-tonne (3.3-short-ton; 3.0-long-ton) spacecraft will orbit the Earth at 400 km (250 mi) altitude for up to seven days with a two-person crew on board. As of February 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the crewed mission is planned to be launched on ISRO's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geosynchronous_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle_Mk_III" title="Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle Mk III">GSLV Mk III</a> in 2023.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-toi-20210217_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-toi-20210217-132">[130]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Space_station">Space station<span class="anchor" id="Space_Station"></span></span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=35" title="Edit section: Space station">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>India plans to build a <a href="/wiki/Space_station" title="Space station">space station</a> as a follow-up programme to <i><a href="/wiki/Gaganyaan" title="Gaganyaan">Gaganyaan</a></i>. ISRO chairman <a href="/wiki/K._Sivan" title="K. Sivan">K. Sivan</a> has said that India will not join the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station_programme" title="International Space Station programme">International Space Station programme</a> and will instead build a 20-tonne (22-short-ton; 20-long-ton) space station on its own.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[131]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[132]</a></sup> It is expected to be placed in a low Earth orbit at 400 kilometres (250 mi) altitude and be capable of harbouring three humans for 15–20 days. The rough time-frame is five to seven years after completion of the <i>Gaganyaan</i> project.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[133]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[134]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Planetary_sciences_and_astronomy">Planetary sciences and astronomy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=36" title="Edit section: Planetary sciences and astronomy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>ISRO and <a href="/wiki/Tata_Institute_of_Fundamental_Research" title="Tata Institute of Fundamental Research">Tata Institute of Fundamental Research</a> have operated a balloon launch base at Hyderabad since 1967.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ISRO_balloon_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-ISRO_balloon-137">[135]</a></sup> Its proximity to the geo-magnetic equator,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[136]</a></sup> where both primary and secondary <a href="/wiki/Cosmic_ray" title="Cosmic ray">cosmic ray</a> fluxes are low, makes it an ideal location to study <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diffuse_X-ray_background" title="Diffuse X-ray background">diffuse cosmic X-ray background</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ISRO_balloon_137-1"><a href="#cite_note-ISRO_balloon-137">[135]</a></sup>
</p><p>ISRO played a role in the discovery of three species of bacteria in the upper stratosphere at an altitude between 20–40 km (12–25 mi). The bacteria, highly resistant to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ultra-violet_radiation" title="Ultra-violet radiation">ultra-violet radiation</a>, are not found elsewhere on Earth, leading to speculation on whether they are extraterrestrial in origin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[137]</a></sup> They are considered <a href="/wiki/Extremophile" title="Extremophile">extremophiles</a>, and named as <i>Bacillus isronensis</i> in recognition of ISRO's contribution in the balloon experiments, which led to its discovery, <i>Bacillus aryabhata</i> after India's celebrated ancient astronomer <a href="/wiki/Aryabhata" title="Aryabhata">Aryabhata</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/Janibacter_hoylei" title="Janibacter hoylei">Janibacter hoylei</a></i> after the distinguished astrophysicist <a href="/wiki/Fred_Hoyle" title="Fred Hoyle">Fred Hoyle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[138]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Astrosat">Astrosat</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=37" title="Edit section: Astrosat">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Astrosat" title="Astrosat">Astrosat</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Astrosat-1_in_deployed_configuration.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="939" decoding="async" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Astrosat-1_in_deployed_configuration.png/220px-Astrosat-1_in_deployed_configuration.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Astrosat-1_in_deployed_configuration.png/330px-Astrosat-1_in_deployed_configuration.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Astrosat-1_in_deployed_configuration.png/440px-Astrosat-1_in_deployed_configuration.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Astrosat-1_in_deployed_configuration.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Astrosat-1 in deployed configuration</div></div></div>
<p>Launched in 2015, Astrosat is India's first dedicated multi-wavelength <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Space_observatory" title="Space observatory">space observatory</a>. Its observation study includes <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Active_galactic_nuclei" title="Active galactic nuclei">active galactic nuclei</a>, hot <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_dwarfs" title="White dwarfs">white dwarfs</a>, pulsations of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pulsars" title="Pulsars">pulsars</a>, binary star systems, and <a href="/wiki/Supermassive_black_hole" title="Supermassive black hole">supermassive black holes</a> located at the centre of the <a href="/wiki/Galaxy" title="Galaxy">galaxy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[139]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Extraterrestrial_exploration">Extraterrestrial exploration</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=38" title="Edit section: Extraterrestrial exploration">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Lunar_exploration">Lunar exploration</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=39" title="Edit section: Lunar exploration">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan_programme" title="Chandrayaan programme">Chandrayaan programme</a></div>
<p>Chandryaan (<abbr style="font-size:85%" title="literal translation">lit.</abbr><span style="white-space: nowrap;"> </span>'Mooncraft') are India's series of lunar exploration spacecraft. The initial mission included an orbiter and controlled impact probe while later missions include landers, rovers and sampling missions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Episode_90_108-1"><a href="#cite_note-Episode_90-108">[106]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[140]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>Chandrayaan-1</dt></dl>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan-1" title="Chandrayaan-1">Chandrayaan-1</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CY1_2007_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="354" data-file-width="547" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/CY1_2007_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-CY1_2007_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/CY1_2007_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-CY1_2007_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/CY1_2007_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-CY1_2007_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CY1_2007_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Rendering of <a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan-1" title="Chandrayaan-1">Chandrayaan-1</a> spacecraft</div></div></div>
<p>Chandrayaan-1 was India's first mission to the Moon. The robotic lunar exploration mission included a lunar orbiter and an impactor called the <a href="/wiki/Moon_Impact_Probe" title="Moon Impact Probe">Moon Impact Probe</a>. ISRO launched it using a modified version of the PSLV on 22 October 2008 from Satish Dhawan Space Centre. It entered lunar orbit on 8 November 2008, carrying high-resolution remote sensing equipment for visible, near infrared, and soft and hard X-ray frequencies. During its 312-day operational period (two years were planned), it surveyed the lunar surface to produce a complete map of its chemical characteristics and three-dimensional topography. The polar regions were of special interest, as they had possible <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lunar_ice" title="Lunar ice">ice</a> deposits. Chandrayaan-1 carried 11 instruments: five Indian and six from foreign institutes and space agencies (including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Aeronautics_and_Space_Administration" title="National Aeronautics and Space Administration">NASA</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">ESA</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Bulgarian Academy of Sciences">Bulgarian Academy of Sciences</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brown_University" title="Brown University">Brown University</a> and other European and North American institutions and companies), which were carried for free. The mission team was awarded the <a href="/wiki/American_Institute_of_Aeronautics_and_Astronautics" title="American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics">American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics</a> SPACE 2009 award,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[141]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/International_Lunar_Exploration_Working_Group" title="International Lunar Exploration Working Group">International Lunar Exploration Working Group</a>'s International Co-operation award in 2008,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[142]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Space_Society" title="National Space Society">National Space Society</a>'s 2009 <a href="/wiki/Space_Pioneer_Awards" title="Space Pioneer Awards">Space Pioneer Award</a> in the science and engineering category.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[144]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>Chandrayaan-2</dt></dl>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan-2" title="Chandrayaan-2">Chandrayaan-2</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GSLV_Mk_III_M1,_Chandrayaan-2_-_Vikram_lander_mounted_on_top_of_orbiter.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="7360" data-file-width="4912" decoding="async" height="330" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/GSLV_Mk_III_M1%2C_Chandrayaan-2_-_Vikram_lander_mounted_on_top_of_orbiter.jpg/220px-GSLV_Mk_III_M1%2C_Chandrayaan-2_-_Vikram_lander_mounted_on_top_of_orbiter.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/GSLV_Mk_III_M1%2C_Chandrayaan-2_-_Vikram_lander_mounted_on_top_of_orbiter.jpg/330px-GSLV_Mk_III_M1%2C_Chandrayaan-2_-_Vikram_lander_mounted_on_top_of_orbiter.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/GSLV_Mk_III_M1%2C_Chandrayaan-2_-_Vikram_lander_mounted_on_top_of_orbiter.jpg/440px-GSLV_Mk_III_M1%2C_Chandrayaan-2_-_Vikram_lander_mounted_on_top_of_orbiter.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GSLV_Mk_III_M1,_Chandrayaan-2_-_Vikram_lander_mounted_on_top_of_orbiter.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Vikram</i> lander mounted on top of the <a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan-2" title="Chandrayaan-2">Chandrayaan-2</a> orbiter</div></div></div>
<p>Chandrayaan-2, the second mission to the Moon, which included an orbiter, a lander and a rover. It was launched on a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geosynchronous_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle_Mark_III" title="Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle Mark III">Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle Mark III</a> (GSLV-MkIII) on 22 July 2019, consisting of a lunar orbiter, the Vikram lander, and the Pragyan lunar rover, all developed in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[145]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gslv3_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-gslv3-148">[146]</a></sup> It was the first mission meant to explore the little-explored <a href="/wiki/Lunar_south_pole" title="Lunar south pole">lunar south pole</a> region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[147]</a></sup> The objective of the Chandrayaan-2 mission was to land a robotic rover to conduct various studies on the lunar surface.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[148]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <i>Vikram</i> lander, carrying the <i>Pragyan</i> rover, was scheduled to land on the near side of the Moon, in the south polar region at a latitude of about 70° S at approximately 1:50 am(IST) on 7 September 2019. However, the lander deviated from its intended trajectory starting from an altitude of 2.1 km (1.3 mi), and <a href="/wiki/Telemetry" title="Telemetry">telemetry</a> was lost seconds before touchdown was expected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[149]</a></sup> A review board concluded that the crash-landing was caused by a <a href="/wiki/Software" title="Software">software</a> glitch.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Failure_report_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-Failure_report-152">[150]</a></sup> The lunar orbiter was efficiently positioned in an optimal lunar orbit, extending its expected service time from one year to seven.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[151]</a></sup> There will be another attempt to soft-land on the Moon in 2023, without an orbiter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tie-20220104_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-tie-20220104-154">[152]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mars_exploration">Mars exploration</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=40" title="Edit section: Mars exploration">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<dl><dt>Mars Orbiter Mission <i>(MOM)</i> or <i>(Mangalyaan-1)</i></dt></dl>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mars_Orbiter_Mission" title="Mars Orbiter Mission">Mars Orbiter Mission</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mars_Orbiter_Mission_-_India_-_ArtistsConcept.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1500" data-file-width="2254" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Mars_Orbiter_Mission_-_India_-_ArtistsConcept.jpg/220px-Mars_Orbiter_Mission_-_India_-_ArtistsConcept.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Mars_Orbiter_Mission_-_India_-_ArtistsConcept.jpg/330px-Mars_Orbiter_Mission_-_India_-_ArtistsConcept.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Mars_Orbiter_Mission_-_India_-_ArtistsConcept.jpg/440px-Mars_Orbiter_Mission_-_India_-_ArtistsConcept.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mars_Orbiter_Mission_-_India_-_ArtistsConcept.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Artist's rendering of the <a href="/wiki/Mars_Orbiter_Mission" title="Mars Orbiter Mission">Mars Orbiter Mission</a> spacecraft, with <a href="/wiki/Mars" title="Mars">Mars</a> in the background</div></div></div>
<p>The Mars Orbiter Mission (MOM), informally known as <i>Mangalyaan</i><big><b>(</b>lit. 'Marscraft'<b>)</b></big>, was launched into Earth <a href="/wiki/Orbit" title="Orbit">orbit</a> on 5 November 2013 by the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) and has entered Mars orbit on 24 September 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-prelaunch_Oct_2013_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-prelaunch_Oct_2013-155">[153]</a></sup> India thus became the first country to have a space probe enter Mars orbit on its first attempt. It was completed at a record low cost of $74 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p>MOM was placed into Mars orbit on 24 September 2014. The spacecraft had a launch mass of 1,337 kg (2,948 lb), with 15 kg (33 lb) of five scientific instruments as payload.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MOMIsro_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-MOMIsro-157">[155]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MOMSpacecraft_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-MOMSpacecraft-158">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>The National Space Society awarded the Mars Orbiter Mission team the 2015 Space Pioneer Award in the science and engineering category.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[157]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[158]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Future_projects">Future projects</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=41" title="Edit section: Future projects">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>ISRO is developing and operationalising more powerful and less pollutive rocket engines so it can eventually develop much heavier rockets. It also plans to develop electric and nuclear propulsion for satellites and spacecrafts to reduce their weight and extend their service lives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[159]</a></sup> Long-term plans may include crewed landings on Moon and other planets as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HTSep20_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-HTSep20-162">[160]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Launch_vehicles_and_engines">Launch vehicles and engines</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=42" title="Edit section: Launch vehicles and engines">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Semi-cryogenic_engine">Semi-cryogenic engine</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=43" title="Edit section: Semi-cryogenic engine">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/SCE-200" title="SCE-200">SCE-200</a></div>
<p>SCE-200 is a rocket-grade <a href="/wiki/Kerosene" title="Kerosene">kerosene</a> (dubbed "ISROsene") and <a href="/wiki/Liquid_oxygen" title="Liquid oxygen">liquid oxygen</a> (LOX)-based semi-cryogenic rocket engine inspired by <a href="/wiki/RD-120" title="RD-120">RD-120</a>. The engine will be less polluting and far more powerful. When combined with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GSLV_Mark_III" title="GSLV Mark III">GSLV Mark III</a>, it will boost its payload capacity; it will be clustered in future to power India's heavy rockets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WIONMar21_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-WIONMar21-163">[161]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Methalox_engine">Methalox engine</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=44" title="Edit section: Methalox engine">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Reusable <a href="/wiki/Methane" title="Methane">methane</a> and LOX-based engines are under development. Methane is less pollutive, leaves no residue and hence the engine needs very little <a href="/wiki/Remanufacturing" title="Remanufacturing">refurbishment</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WIONMar21_163-1"><a href="#cite_note-WIONMar21-163">[161]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Liquid_Propulsion_Systems_Centre" title="Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre">LPSC</a> began cold flow tests of engine prototypes in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lpsctimeline_29-1"><a href="#cite_note-lpsctimeline-29">[27]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Modular_heavy_rockets">Modular heavy rockets</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=45" title="Edit section: Modular heavy rockets">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Unified_Launch_Vehicle" title="Unified Launch Vehicle">Unified Launch Vehicle</a></div>
<p>ISRO is studying <a href="/wiki/Heavy-lift_launch_vehicle" title="Heavy-lift launch vehicle">heavy</a> (HLV) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Super-heavy_lift_launch_vehicle" title="Super-heavy lift launch vehicle">super-heavy lift launch vehicles</a> (SHLV). Modular launchers are being designed, with interchangeable parts, to reduce production time. A 10-tonne (11-short-ton; 9.8-long-ton) capacity HLV and an SHLV capable of delivering 50–100 tonnes (55–110 short tons; 49–98 long tons) into orbit have been mentioned in statements and presentations from ISRO officials.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[162]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[163]</a></sup>
</p><p>The agency intends to develop a launcher in the 2020s which can carry nearly 16 t (18 short tons; 16 long tons) to <a href="/wiki/Geostationary_transfer_orbit" title="Geostationary transfer orbit">geostationary transfer orbit</a>, nearly four times the capacity of the existing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GSLV_Mark_III" title="GSLV Mark III">GSLV Mark III</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WIONMar21_163-2"><a href="#cite_note-WIONMar21-163">[161]</a></sup> A rocket family of five medium to heavy-lift class modular rockets described as either "Unified Modular Launch Vehicles" (UMLV) or "<a href="/wiki/Unified_Launch_Vehicle" title="Unified Launch Vehicle">Unified Launch Vehicles</a>" (ULV) are being planned which will share parts and will replace ISRO's existing PSLV, GSLV and LVM3 rockets completely. The rocket family will be powered by <a href="/wiki/SCE-200" title="SCE-200">SCE-200</a> cryogenic engine and will have a capacity of lifting from 4.9 t (5.4 short tons; 4.8 long tons) to 16 t (18 short tons; 16 long tons) to geostationary transfer orbit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WIONSep21_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-WIONSep21-166">[164]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Reusable_launchers">Reusable launchers</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=46" title="Edit section: Reusable launchers">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/RLV-TD" title="RLV-TD">RLV-TD</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Launch_of_RLV-TD_HEX01_from_First_Launch_Pad_of_Satish_Dhawan_Space_Centre,_Sriharikota_(SDSC_SHAR)_02.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2464" data-file-width="1640" decoding="async" height="331" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Launch_of_RLV-TD_HEX01_from_First_Launch_Pad_of_Satish_Dhawan_Space_Centre%2C_Sriharikota_%28SDSC_SHAR%29_02.jpg/220px-Launch_of_RLV-TD_HEX01_from_First_Launch_Pad_of_Satish_Dhawan_Space_Centre%2C_Sriharikota_%28SDSC_SHAR%29_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Launch_of_RLV-TD_HEX01_from_First_Launch_Pad_of_Satish_Dhawan_Space_Centre%2C_Sriharikota_%28SDSC_SHAR%29_02.jpg/330px-Launch_of_RLV-TD_HEX01_from_First_Launch_Pad_of_Satish_Dhawan_Space_Centre%2C_Sriharikota_%28SDSC_SHAR%29_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Launch_of_RLV-TD_HEX01_from_First_Launch_Pad_of_Satish_Dhawan_Space_Centre%2C_Sriharikota_%28SDSC_SHAR%29_02.jpg/440px-Launch_of_RLV-TD_HEX01_from_First_Launch_Pad_of_Satish_Dhawan_Space_Centre%2C_Sriharikota_%28SDSC_SHAR%29_02.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Launch_of_RLV-TD_HEX01_from_First_Launch_Pad_of_Satish_Dhawan_Space_Centre,_Sriharikota_(SDSC_SHAR)_02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>RLV-TD HEX01 from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Satish_Dhawan_Space_Centre_First_Launch_Pad" title="Satish Dhawan Space Centre First Launch Pad">Satish Dhawan Space Centre First Launch Pad</a> (SDSC SHAR) on 23 May 2016.</div></div></div>
<p>There have been two reusable launcher projects ongoing at ISRO. One is the ADMIRE test vehicle, conceived as a <a href="/wiki/VTVL" title="VTVL">VTVL</a> system and another is RLV-TD programme, being run to develop a spacecraft similar to the American <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle" title="Space Shuttle">Space Shuttle</a> which will be <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/VTHL" title="VTHL">launched vertically but land like a plane</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>To realise a fully re-usable <a href="/wiki/Two-stage-to-orbit" title="Two-stage-to-orbit">two-stage-to-orbit</a> (TSTO) launch vehicle, a series of technology demonstration missions have been conceived. For this purpose, the winged Reusable Launch Vehicle Technology Demonstrator (<a href="/wiki/RLV-TD" title="RLV-TD">RLV-TD</a>) has been configured. The RLV-TD acts as a flying <a href="/wiki/Testbed" title="Testbed">testbed</a> to evaluate various technologies such as hypersonic flight, autonomous landing, powered cruise flight, and hypersonic flight using air-breathing propulsion. First in the series of demonstration trials was the <a href="/wiki/Hypersonic_Flight_Experiment" title="Hypersonic Flight Experiment">Hypersonic Flight Experiment</a> (HEX). ISRO launched the prototype's test flight, RLV-TD, from the Sriharikota spaceport in February 2016. It weighs around 1.5 t (1.7 short tons; 1.5 long tons) and flew up to a height of 70 km (43 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[166]</a></sup> HEX was completed five months later. A scaled-up version of it could serve as fly-back booster stage for the winged TSTO concept.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[167]</a></sup> HEX will be followed by a landing experiment (LEX) and return flight experiment (REX).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[168]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>Small Satellite Launch Vehicle</dt></dl>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Small_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle" title="Small Satellite Launch Vehicle">Small Satellite Launch Vehicle</a></div>
<p>The Small Satellite Launch Vehicle (SSLV) is a compact <a href="/wiki/Small-lift_launch_vehicle" title="Small-lift launch vehicle">small-lift launch vehicle</a> primarily aimed at the small satellites market. It can be quickly assembled with low power and hence allows more frequent launches. The SSLV can place 500 kg (1,100 lb) in 500 km (310 mi) low Earth orbit and 300 kg (660 lb) in Sun-synchronous orbit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[169]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Spacecraft_propulsion_and_power">Spacecraft propulsion and power</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=47" title="Edit section: Spacecraft propulsion and power">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<dl><dt>Electric thrusters</dt></dl>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electrically_powered_spacecraft_propulsion" title="Electrically powered spacecraft propulsion">Electrically powered spacecraft propulsion</a></div>
<p>India has been working on replacing conventional chemical propulsion with <a href="/wiki/Hall-effect_thruster" title="Hall-effect thruster">Hall-effect</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pulsed_plasma_thruster" title="Pulsed plasma thruster">plasma</a> thrusters which would make spacecraft lighter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WIONMar21_163-3"><a href="#cite_note-WIONMar21-163">[161]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/GSAT-4" title="GSAT-4">GSAT-4</a> was the first Indian spacecraft to carry electric thrusters, but it failed to reach orbit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[170]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GSAT-9" title="GSAT-9">GSAT-9</a> launched later in 2017, had <a href="/wiki/Xenon" title="Xenon">xenon</a>-based electric propulsion system for in-orbit functions of the spacecraft. <a href="/wiki/GSAT-20" title="GSAT-20">GSAT-20</a> is expected to be the first fully electric satellite from India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newsexpress_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-newsexpress-173">[171]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[172]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>Alpha source thermoelectric propulsion technology</dt></dl>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Radioisotope_Thermoelectric_Generator" title="Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generator">Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generator</a></div>
<p>Radioisotope thermoelectric generator (RTG), also called alpha source thermoelectric technology by ISRO, is a type of <a href="/wiki/Atomic_battery" title="Atomic battery">atomic battery</a> which uses nuclear <a href="/wiki/Decay_heat" title="Decay heat">decay heat</a> from radioactive material to power the spacecraft.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NPE3_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-NPE3-175">[173]</a></sup> In January 2021, the <a href="/wiki/U_R_Rao_Satellite_Centre" title="U R Rao Satellite Centre">U R Rao Satellite Centre</a> issued an Expression of Interest (EoI) for design and development of a 100-<a href="/wiki/Watt" title="Watt">watt</a> RTG. RTGs ensure much longer spacecraft life and have less mass than solar panels on satellites. Development of RTGs will allow ISRO to undertake long-duration deep space missions to the outer planets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RTEG_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-RTEG-176">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[175]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Extraterrestrial_probes">Extraterrestrial probes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=48" title="Edit section: Extraterrestrial probes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>

<dl><dt>Lunar exploration</dt></dl>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan-3" title="Chandrayaan-3">Chandrayaan-3</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LUPEX" title="LUPEX">LUPEX</a></div>
<p>Chandryaan-3 is India's planned second attempt to soft-land on the Moon after the failure of <a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan-2" title="Chandrayaan-2">Chandrayaan-2</a>. The mission will only include a lander-rover set and will communicate with the orbiter from the previous mission. The technology demonstrated in a successful Moon landing will be used in a joint Indo-Japanese <a href="/wiki/Lunar_Polar_Exploration_Mission" title="Lunar Polar Exploration Mission">Lunar Polar Exploration Mission</a> for sampling and analysis of lunar soil.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wire_Nov2019_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wire_Nov2019-179">[177]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>Mars exploration</dt></dl>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mars_Orbiter_Mission_2" title="Mars Orbiter Mission 2">Mars Orbiter Mission 2</a></div>
<p>The next Mars mission, Mars Orbiter Mission 2 or Mangalyaan 2, has been proposed for launch in 2024.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RS_20190718_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-RS_20190718-180">[178]</a></sup> The newer spacecraft will be significantly heavier and better equipped than its predecessor;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Episode_90_108-2"><a href="#cite_note-Episode_90-108">[106]</a></sup> it will only have an orbiter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[179]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>Venus exploration</dt></dl>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shukrayaan-I" title="Shukrayaan-I">Shukrayaan-I</a></div>
<p>ISRO is considering an orbiter mission to Venus called <i><a href="/wiki/Shukrayaan-1" title="Shukrayaan-1">Shukrayaan-1</a></i>, that could launch as early as 2023 to study <a href="/wiki/Atmosphere_of_Venus" title="Atmosphere of Venus">the planet's atmosphere</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Venorb_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-Venorb-182">[180]</a></sup> Some funds for preliminary studies were allocated in the 2017–18 Indian budget under Space Sciences;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[182]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-indiabudget.gov.in_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-indiabudget.gov.in-185">[183]</a></sup> solicitations for potential instruments were requested in 2017<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A_of_O_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-A_of_O-186">[184]</a></sup> and 2018. A mission to Venus is scheduled for 2025 that will include a payload instrument called Venus Infrared Atmospheric Gases Linker (VIRAL) which has been co-developed with the <a href="/wiki/Laboratoire_atmosph%C3%A8res,_milieux,_observations_spatiales" title="Laboratoire atmosphères, milieux, observations spatiales">Laboratoire atmosphères, milieux, observations spatiales</a> (LATMOS) under <a href="/wiki/French_National_Centre_for_Scientific_Research" title="French National Centre for Scientific Research">French National Centre for Scientific Research</a> (CNRS) and <a href="/wiki/Roscosmos" title="Roscosmos">Roscosmos</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[185]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>Solar probes</dt></dl>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Aditya-L1" title="Aditya-L1">Aditya-L1</a></div>
<p>In 2022 ISRO plans to launch the 400 kg (880 lb) Aditya-L1, a mission to study the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Solar_corona" title="Solar corona">Solar corona</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[188]</a></sup> It is the first Indian space-based solar <a href="/wiki/Coronagraph" title="Coronagraph">coronagraph</a> to study the corona in visible and near-<a href="/wiki/Infrared" title="Infrared">infrared</a> bands. Originally planned during the heightened solar activity period in 2012, Aditya-L1 was postponed to 2021 due to the extensive work involved in its manufacture, and other technical aspects. The main objective of the mission is to study <a href="/wiki/Coronal_mass_ejection" title="Coronal mass ejection">coronal mass ejections</a> (CMEs), their properties (the structure and evolution of their magnetic fields for example), and consequently constrain parameters that affect <a href="/wiki/Space_weather" title="Space weather">space weather</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AdityaISRO_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-AdityaISRO-191">[189]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>Asteroids and outer solar system</dt></dl>
<p>Conceptual studies are underway for spacecraft destined for the asteroids and <a href="/wiki/Jupiter" title="Jupiter">Jupiter</a>, as well, in the long term. The ideal launch window to send a spacecraft to Jupiter occurs every 33 months. If the mission to <a href="/wiki/Jupiter" title="Jupiter">Jupiter</a> is launched, a flyby of <a href="/wiki/Venus" title="Venus">Venus</a> would be required.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[190]</a></sup> Development of <a href="/wiki/Radioisotope_thermoelectric_generator" title="Radioisotope thermoelectric generator">RTEG</a> power might allow the agency to further undertake deeper space missions to the other outer planets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RTEG_176-1"><a href="#cite_note-RTEG-176">[174]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Space_telescopes_and_observatories">Space telescopes and observatories</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=49" title="Edit section: Space telescopes and observatories">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<dl><dt>AstroSat-2</dt></dl>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/AstroSat-2" title="AstroSat-2">AstroSat-2</a></div>
<p>AstroSat-2 is the successor to the Astrosat mission.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TOI1_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-TOI1-193">[191]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>XPoSat</dt></dl>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/X-ray_Polarimeter_Satellite" title="X-ray Polarimeter Satellite">X-ray Polarimeter Satellite</a></div>
<p>The X-ray Polarimeter Satellite (<a href="/wiki/X-ray_Polarimeter_Satellite" title="X-ray Polarimeter Satellite">XPoSat</a>) is a planned mission to study <a href="/wiki/Polarization_(waves)" title="Polarization (waves)">polarisation</a>. It is planned to have a mission life of five years and is planned to be launched in 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[192]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Annadurai_2019_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-Annadurai_2019-195">[193]</a></sup> The spacecraft is planned to carry the Polarimeter Instrument in X-rays (POLIX) payload which will study the degree and angle of polarisation of bright astronomical <a href="/wiki/X-ray" title="X-ray">X-ray</a> sources in the energy range 5–30 keV.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[194]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>Exoworlds</dt></dl>
<p>Exoworlds is a joint proposal by ISRO, <a href="/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Space_Science_and_Technology" title="Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology">IIST</a> and the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Cambridge" title="University of Cambridge">University of Cambridge</a> for a space telescope dedicated for atmospheric studies of <a href="/wiki/Exoplanet" title="Exoplanet">exoplanets</a>, planned for 2025.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[196]</a></sup>
</p>
