<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Applications">Applications</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=51" title="Edit section: Applications">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Telecommunication">Telecommunication</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=52" title="Edit section: Telecommunication">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>India uses its satellite communication network – one of the largest in the world – for applications such as land management, water resources management, natural disaster forecasting, radio networking, weather forecasting, meteorological imaging and computer communication.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bhaskaranarayana1738_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bhaskaranarayana1738-204">[202]</a></sup> Business, administrative services, and schemes such as the <a href="/wiki/National_Informatics_Centre" title="National Informatics Centre">National Informatics Centre</a> (NIC) are direct beneficiaries of applied satellite technology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-205">[203]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=53" title="Edit section: Military">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Integrated_Space_Cell" title="Integrated Space Cell">Integrated Space Cell</a>, under the <a href="/wiki/Integrated_Defence_Staff" title="Integrated Defence Staff">Integrated Defence Staff</a> headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(India)" title="Ministry of Defence (India)">Ministry of Defence</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iss_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-iss-206">[204]</a></sup> has been set up to utilise more effectively the country's space-based assets for military purposes and to look into threats to these assets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[206]</a></sup> This command will leverage space technology including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Satellites" title="Satellites">satellites</a>. Unlike an aerospace command, where the Air Force controls most of its activities, the Integrated Space Cell envisages cooperation and coordination between the three services as well as civilian agencies dealing with space.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iss_206-1"><a href="#cite_note-iss-206">[204]</a></sup>
</p><p>With 14 satellites, including <a href="/wiki/GSAT-7A" title="GSAT-7A">GSAT-7A</a> for exclusive military use and the rest as dual-use satellites, India has the fourth largest number of satellites active in the sky which includes satellites for the exclusive use of <a href="/wiki/Indian_Air_Force" title="Indian Air Force">its air force</a> (IAF) and <a href="/wiki/Indian_Navy" title="Indian Navy">navy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-howmany_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-howmany-209">[207]</a></sup> GSAT-7A, an advanced military communications satellite built exclusively for the Air Force,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-210">[208]</a></sup> is similar to the Navy's <a href="/wiki/GSAT-7" title="GSAT-7">GSAT-7</a>, and GSAT-7A will enhance the IAF's <a href="/wiki/Network-centric_warfare" title="Network-centric warfare">network-centric warfare capabilities</a> by interlinking different ground radar stations, ground airbases and <a href="/wiki/Airborne_early_warning_and_control" title="Airborne early warning and control">airborne early warning and control (AWACS)</a> aircraft such as the <a href="/wiki/Beriev_A-50" title="Beriev A-50">Beriev A-50</a> <a href="/wiki/EL/W-2090" title="EL/W-2090">Phalcon</a> and <a href="/wiki/DRDO_AEW%26CS" title="DRDO AEW&CS">DRDO AEW&CS</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_210-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-210">[208]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-skymil1_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-skymil1-211">[209]</a></sup>
</p><p>GSAT-7A will also be used by the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Army" title="Indian Army">Army</a>'s Aviation Corps for its helicopters and <a href="/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle" title="Unmanned aerial vehicle">unmanned aerial vehicle</a> (UAV) operations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_210-2"><a href="#cite_note-:0-210">[208]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-skymil1_211-1"><a href="#cite_note-skymil1-211">[209]</a></sup> In 2013, ISRO launched GSAT-7 for the exclusive use of the Navy to monitor the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean Region</a> (IOR) with the satellite's 2,000-nautical-mile (3,700 km; 2,300 mi) 'footprint' and real-time input capabilities to Indian warships, submarines and maritime aircraft.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-howmany_209-1"><a href="#cite_note-howmany-209">[207]</a></sup> To boost the network-centric operations of the IAF, ISRO launched <a href="/wiki/GSAT-7A" title="GSAT-7A">GSAT-7A</a> in December 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[210]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-howmany_209-2"><a href="#cite_note-howmany-209">[207]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/RISAT" title="RISAT">RISAT</a> series of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Radar_imaging" title="Radar imaging">radar-imaging</a> <a href="/wiki/Earth_observation_satellite" title="Earth observation satellite">earth observation satellites</a> is also meant for Military use.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[211]</a></sup> ISRO launched <a href="/wiki/EMISAT" title="EMISAT">EMISAT</a> on 1 April 2019. EMISAT is a 436-kilogram (961 lb) electronic intelligence (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ELINT" title="ELINT">ELINT</a>) satellite. It will improve the situational awareness of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Armed_Forces" title="Indian Armed Forces">Indian Armed Forces</a> by providing information and the location of hostile radars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[212]</a></sup>
</p><p>India's satellites and satellite launch vehicles have had military spin-offs. While India's 150–200-kilometre (93–124 <a href="/wiki/Mile" title="Mile">mi</a>) range <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prithvi_missile" title="Prithvi missile">Prithvi missile</a> is not derived from the Indian space programme, the intermediate range <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agni_missile" title="Agni missile">Agni missile</a> is derived from the Indian space programme's SLV-3. In its early years, under Sarabhai and Dhawan, ISRO opposed military applications for its dual-use projects such as the SLV-3. Eventually, the <a href="/wiki/Defence_Research_and_Development_Organisation" title="Defence Research and Development Organisation">Defence Research and Development Organisation</a> (DRDO)-based missile programme borrowed staff and technology from ISRO. Missile scientist <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/A.P.J._Abdul_Kalam" title="A.P.J. Abdul Kalam">A.P.J. Abdul Kalam</a> (later elected <a href="/wiki/President_of_India" title="President of India">president</a>), who had headed the SLV-3 project at ISRO, took over as missile programme at DRDO. About a dozen scientists accompanied him, helping to design the Agni missile using the SLV-3's solid fuel first stage and a liquid-fuel (Prithvi-missile-derived) second stage. The IRS and INSAT satellites were primarily intended, and used, for civilian-economic applications, but they also offered military spin-offs. In 1996 the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(India)" title="Ministry of Defence (India)">Ministry of Defence</a> temporarily blocked the use of <a href="/wiki/IRS-1C" title="IRS-1C">IRS-1C</a> by India's <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Environment,_Forest_and_Climate_Change" title="Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change">environmental</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Agriculture_and_Farmers%27_Welfare" title="Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers' Welfare">agricultural ministries</a> in order to monitor ballistic missiles near India's borders. In 1997, the Air Force's "Airpower Doctrine" aspired to use space assets for surveillance and battle management.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mistry94_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-mistry94-215">[213]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Academic">Academic</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=54" title="Edit section: Academic">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Institutions like the <a href="/wiki/Indira_Gandhi_National_Open_University" title="Indira Gandhi National Open University">Indira Gandhi National Open University</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Institutes_of_Technology" title="Indian Institutes of Technology">Indian Institutes of Technology</a> use satellites for educational applications.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bhaskaranarayana1744_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bhaskaranarayana1744-216">[214]</a></sup> Between 1975 and 1976, India conducted its largest sociological programme using space technology, reaching 2,400<span class="nowrap"> </span>villages through video programming in local languages aimed at educational development via <a href="/wiki/ATS-6" title="ATS-6">ATS-6</a> technology developed by NASA.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bhaskaranarayana1737_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bhaskaranarayana1737-217">[215]</a></sup> This experiment—named <a href="/wiki/Satellite_Instructional_Television_Experiment" title="Satellite Instructional Television Experiment">Satellite Instructional Television Experiment</a> (SITE)—conducted large-scale video broadcasts resulting in significant improvement in rural education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bhaskaranarayana1737_217-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bhaskaranarayana1737-217">[215]</a></sup> Education could reach remote rural areas with the help of the above programs.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Telemedicine">Telemedicine</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=55" title="Edit section: Telemedicine">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>ISRO has applied its technology for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Telemedicine" title="Telemedicine">telemedicine</a>, directly connecting patients in rural areas to medical professionals in urban locations via satellite.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bhaskaranarayana1744_216-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bhaskaranarayana1744-216">[214]</a></sup> Since high-quality healthcare is not universally available in some of the remote areas of India, patients in those areas are diagnosed and analysed by doctors in urban centers in real time via <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Video_conferencing" title="Video conferencing">video conferencing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bhaskaranarayana1744_216-2"><a href="#cite_note-Bhaskaranarayana1744-216">[214]</a></sup> The patient is then advised on medicine and treatment,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bhaskaranarayana1744_216-3"><a href="#cite_note-Bhaskaranarayana1744-216">[214]</a></sup> and treated by the staff at one of the 'super-specialty hospitals' per instructions from those doctors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bhaskaranarayana1744_216-4"><a href="#cite_note-Bhaskaranarayana1744-216">[214]</a></sup> Mobile telemedicine vans are also deployed to visit locations in far-flung areas and provide diagnosis and support to patients.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bhaskaranarayana1744_216-5"><a href="#cite_note-Bhaskaranarayana1744-216">[214]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity_Information_System">Biodiversity Information System</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=56" title="Edit section: Biodiversity Information System">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>ISRO has also helped implement India's Biodiversity Information System, completed in October 2002.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sen490_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-sen490-218">[216]</a></sup> Nirupa Sen details the program: "Based on intensive field sampling and mapping using satellite remote sensing and geospatial modeling tools, maps have been made of vegetation cover on a 1: 250,000 scale. This has been put together in a web-enabled database that links gene-level information of plant species with spatial information in a BIOSPEC database of the ecological hot spot regions, namely <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North-East_India" title="North-East India">northeastern India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_Ghats" title="Western Ghats">Western Ghats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Himalayas" title="Himalayas">Western Himalayas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andaman_and_Nicobar_Islands" title="Andaman and Nicobar Islands">Andaman and Nicobar Islands</a>. This has been made possible with collaboration between the Department of Biotechnology and ISRO."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sen490_218-1"><a href="#cite_note-sen490-218">[216]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cartography">Cartography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=57" title="Edit section: Cartography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The Indian IRS-P5 (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CARTOSAT-1" title="CARTOSAT-1">CARTOSAT-1</a>) was equipped with high-resolution panchromatic equipment to enable it for cartographic purposes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurleson2005136_46-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurleson2005136-46">[44]</a></sup> IRS-P5 (CARTOSAT-1) was followed by a more advanced model named IRS-P6 developed also for agricultural applications.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurleson2005136_46-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurleson2005136-46">[44]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CARTOSAT-2" title="CARTOSAT-2">CARTOSAT-2</a> project, equipped with single panchromatic camera that supported scene-specific on-spot images, succeeded the CARTOSAT-1 project.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurleson2005143_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurleson2005143-219">[217]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Spin-offs">Spin-offs</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=58" title="Edit section: Spin-offs">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/ISRO_spinoff_technologies" title="ISRO spinoff technologies">ISRO spinoff technologies</a></div>
<p>ISRO's research has been diverted into spin-offs to develop various technologies for other sectors. Examples include <a href="/wiki/Prosthesis" title="Prosthesis">bionic limbs</a> for people without limbs, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Silica_aerogel" title="Silica aerogel">silica aerogel</a> to keep Indian soldiers serving in extremely cold areas warm, distress alert transmitters for accidents, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doppler_weather_radar" title="Doppler weather radar">Doppler weather radar</a> and various sensors and machines for inspection work in engineering industries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[218]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[219]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="International_cooperations">International cooperations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=59" title="Edit section: International cooperations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>ISRO has signed various formal cooperative arrangements in the form of either Agreements or Memoranda of Understanding (MoU) or Framework Agreements with <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>, Australia, <a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">Bahrain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brunei" title="Brunei">Brunei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, Canada, <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>, China, <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a>, France, Germany, <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a>, Italy, Japan, <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuwait" title="Kuwait">Kuwait</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maldives" title="Maldives">Maldives</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mauritius" title="Mauritius">Mauritius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a>, Norway, <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a>, Portugal, <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>, Russia, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Tom%C3%A9_and_Pr%C3%ADncipe" title="São Tomé and Príncipe">São Tomé and Príncipe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>, South Africa, Spain, <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">Sweden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tajikistan" title="Tajikistan">Tajikistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a>, the Netherlands, <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a>, United Kingdom, United States, <a href="/wiki/Uzbekistan" title="Uzbekistan">Uzbekistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>. Formal cooperative instruments have been signed with international multilateral bodies including <a href="/wiki/European_Centre_for_Medium-Range_Weather_Forecasts" title="European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts">European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts</a> (ECMWF), <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Organisation_for_the_Exploitation_of_Meteorological_Satellites" title="European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites">European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites</a> (EUMETSAT), <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a> (ESA) and <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Association_for_Regional_Cooperation" title="South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation">South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation</a> (SAARC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[220]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Notable_collaborative_projects">Notable collaborative projects</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=60" title="Edit section: Notable collaborative projects">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<dl><dt>Chandrayaan-1</dt></dl>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan-1" title="Chandrayaan-1">Chandrayaan-1</a> also carried scientific payloads to the moon from <a href="/wiki/NASA" title="NASA">NASA</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ESA" title="ESA">ESA</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Space_Agency" title="Bulgarian Space Agency">Bulgarian Space Agency</a>, and other institutions/companies in North America and Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[221]</a></sup></li></ul>
<dl><dt>Indo-French satellite missions</dt></dl>
<p>ISRO has two collaborative satellite missions with France's <a href="/wiki/CNES" title="CNES">CNES</a>, namely <a href="/wiki/Megha-Tropiques" title="Megha-Tropiques">Megha-Tropiques</a> to study <a href="/wiki/Water_cycle" title="Water cycle">water cycle</a> in the tropical atmosphere<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram447_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram447-224">[222]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/SARAL" title="SARAL">SARAL</a> for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Altimetry" title="Altimetry">altimetry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[223]</a></sup> A third mission consisting of an earth observation satellite with a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thermal_infrared" title="Thermal infrared">thermal infrared</a> imager, TRISHNA (Thermal infraRed Imaging Satellite for High resolution Natural resource Assessment) is being planned by the two countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[224]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>LUPEX</dt></dl>
<p><a href="/wiki/Lunar_Polar_Exploration_Mission" title="Lunar Polar Exploration Mission">Lunar Polar Exploration Mission</a> is a joint Indo-Japanese mission to study the polar surface of the Moon where India is tasked with providing soft landing technologies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Episode_82_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-Episode_82-227">[225]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>NISAR</dt></dl>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NASA-ISRO_Synthetic_Aperture_Radar" title="NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar">NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar</a> (NISAR) is a joint Indo-US radar project carrying an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L_Band" title="L Band">L Band</a> and an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S_Band" title="S Band">S Band</a> radar. It will be world's first radar imaging satellite to use dual frequencies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[226]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some other notable collaborations include:
</p>
<ul><li>ISRO operates LUT/MCC under the international COSPAS/SARSAT Programme for Search and Rescue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LUT1_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-LUT1-229">[227]</a></sup></li>
<li>India has established a Centre for Space Science and Technology Education in Asia and the Pacific (CSSTE-AP) that is sponsored by the United Nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CSSTEAP1_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-CSSTEAP1-230">[228]</a></sup></li>
<li>India is a member of the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cospas-Sarsat" title="Cospas-Sarsat">Cospas-Sarsat</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Astronautical_Federation" title="International Astronautical Federation">International Astronautical Federation</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/COSPAR" title="COSPAR">Committee on Space Research</a> (COSPAR), <a href="/wiki/Inter-Agency_Space_Debris_Coordination_Committee" title="Inter-Agency Space Debris Coordination Committee">Inter-Agency Space Debris Coordination Committee</a> (IADC), <a href="/wiki/International_Space_University" title="International Space University">International Space University</a>, and the Committee on Earth Observation Satellite (CEOS).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram447_224-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuriRajaram447-224">[222]</a></sup></li>
<li>Contributing to planned <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a> virtual constellation for <a href="/wiki/Remote_sensing" title="Remote sensing">remote sensing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[229]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[230]</a></sup></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Statistics">Statistics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=61" title="Edit section: Statistics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Last updated: 24 October 2022
</p>
<ul><li>Total number of foreign satellites launched by ISRO: 381 (34 countries)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[231]</a></sup></li>
<li>Spacecraft missions: 116<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[232]</a></sup></li>
<li>Launch missions: 86</li>
<li>Student satellites: 13 <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[233]</a></sup></li>
<li>Re-entry missions: 2</li></ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Controversies">Controversies</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=63" title="Edit section: Controversies">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="S-band_spectrum_scam">S-band spectrum scam</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Space_Research_Organisation&action=edit&section=64" title="Edit section: S-band spectrum scam">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In India, <a href="/wiki/Electromagnetic_spectrum" title="Electromagnetic spectrum">electromagnetic spectrum</a>, a scarce resource for wireless communication, is auctioned by the Government of India to telecom companies for use. As an example of its value, in 2010, 20 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Megahertz" title="Megahertz">MHz</a> of <a href="/wiki/3G" title="3G">3G</a> spectrum was <a href="/wiki/Indian_Telecom_Spectrum_Auction" title="Indian Telecom Spectrum Auction">auctioned</a> for <span class="nowrap"><span style="white-space: nowrap">₹</span>677 billion</span> (US$8.5 billion). This part of the spectrum is allocated for terrestrial communication (cell phones). However, in January 2005, Antrix Corporation (commercial arm of ISRO) signed an agreement with Devas Multimedia (a private company formed by former ISRO employees and venture capitalists from the US) for lease of <a href="/wiki/S_band" title="S band">S band</a> transponders (amounting to 70 MHz of spectrum) on two ISRO satellites (GSAT 6 and GSAT 6A) for a price of <span class="nowrap"><span style="white-space: nowrap">₹</span>14 billion</span> (US$180 million), to be paid over a period of 12 years. The spectrum used in these satellites (2500 MHz and above) is allocated by the <a href="/wiki/International_Telecommunication_Union" title="International Telecommunication Union">International Telecommunication Union</a> specifically for satellite-based communication in India. Hypothetically, if the spectrum allocation is changed for utilisation for terrestrial transmission and if this 70 MHz of spectrum were sold at the 2010 auction price of the 3G spectrum, its value would have been over <span class="nowrap"><span style="white-space: nowrap">₹</span>2,000 billion</span> (US$25 billion). This was a hypothetical situation. However, the <a href="/wiki/Comptroller_and_Auditor_General_of_India" title="Comptroller and Auditor General of India">Comptroller and Auditor-General</a> considered this hypothetical situation and estimated the difference between the prices as a loss to the Indian Government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thakur,_Pradeep_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-Thakur,_Pradeep-301">[299]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Behind_the_S-band_spectrum_scandal_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-Behind_the_S-band_spectrum_scandal-302">[300]</a></sup>
</p><p>There were lapses on implementing official procedures. Antrix/ISRO had allocated the capacity of the above two satellites exclusively to Devas Multimedia, while the rules said it should always be non-exclusive. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_India" title="Cabinet of India">Cabinet</a> was misinformed in November 2005 that several service providers were interested in using satellite capacity, while the Devas deal was already signed. Also, the Space Commission was not informed when approving the second satellite (its cost was diluted so that Cabinet approval was not needed). ISRO committed to spending <span class="nowrap"><span style="white-space: nowrap">₹</span>7.66 billion</span> (US$96 million) of public money on building, launching, and operating two satellites that were leased out for Devas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ETDevdas_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-ETDevdas-303">[301]</a></sup>
In late 2009, some ISRO insiders exposed information about the Devas-Antrix deal,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Behind_the_S-band_spectrum_scandal_302-1"><a href="#cite_note-Behind_the_S-band_spectrum_scandal-302">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[302]</a></sup> and the ensuing investigations led to the deal's annulment. <a href="/wiki/G._Madhavan_Nair" title="G. Madhavan Nair">G. Madhavan Nair</a> (ISRO Chairperson when the agreement was signed) was barred from holding any post under the Department of Space. Some former scientists were found guilty of "acts of commission" or "acts of omission". Devas and Deutsche Telekom demanded US$2 billion and US$1 billion, respectively, in damages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[303]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Department_of_Revenue_(India)" title="Department of Revenue (India)">Department of Revenue</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Corporate_Affairs" title="Ministry of Corporate Affairs">Ministry of Corporate Affairs</a> began an inquiry into Devas shareholding.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ETDevdas_303-1"><a href="#cite_note-ETDevdas-303">[301]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Central_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Central Bureau of Investigation">Central Bureau of Investigation</a> registered a case against the accused in the Antrix-Devas deal under Section 120-B, besides Section 420 of IPC and Section 13(2) read with 13(1)(d) of PC Act, 1988 in March 2015 against the then executive director of <a href="/wiki/Antrix_Corporation" title="Antrix Corporation">Antrix Corporation</a>, two officials of a USA-based company, a Bangalore-based private multimedia company, and other unknown officials of the Antrix Corporation or the Department of Space.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[304]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[305]</a></sup>
</p><p>Devas Multimedia started <a href="/wiki/Arbitration" title="Arbitration">arbitration</a> proceedings against Antrix in June 2011. In September 2015, the <a href="/wiki/International_Court_of_Arbitration" title="International Court of Arbitration">International Court of Arbitration</a> of the <a href="/wiki/International_Chamber_of_Commerce" title="International Chamber of Commerce">International Chamber of Commerce</a> ruled in favour of Devas, and directed Antrix to pay US$672 million (Rs 44.35 billion) in damages to Devas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[306]</a></sup> Antrix opposed the Devas plea for tribunal award in the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_High_Court" title="Delhi High Court">Delhi High Court</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[307]</a></sup>
</p>
